nytimes_articles.headline: Moynihan Is Moving to Halve 1993 Tax Increase
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, whose committee will begin work this week on President Clinton's economic plan, said today that under the measure he was contemplating wealthy taxpayers would face only half the tax increase proposed by the President this year, with the full increase not effective until 1994.   "It doesn't feel right to anybody" to make the tax increases retroactive to Jan. 1, Mr. Moynihan said, so he would make the new rates effective on July 1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Meredith S. Saul, John H. Marks
nytimes_articles.abstract: Meredith Stacey Saul, a daughter Dr. and Mrs. Richard B. Saul of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Dr. John H. Marks, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Marks of Penn Valley, Pa. Rabbi David Sandmel performed the ceremony at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; A Selective History of a Decade Defining America
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Fifties   By David Halberstam   Illustrated. 800 pages. Villard Books/ Random House. $27.50.     Many prominent books have been written about the various subjects that David Halberstam covers in "The Fifties," a history of the decade of which he describes himself "a child," having graduated from high school in 1951 and from college in 1955, and having had his values "shaped in that era."

nytimes_articles.headline: More U.N. Appeasement on Bosnia
nytimes_articles.abstract: The West has dithered so pathetically, and Bosnia has suffered so terribly, that Bosnian leaders are justifiably suspicious of the new "joint action program" approved by the U.N. Security Council on Friday in response to Belgrade's grab for a Greater Serbia.   The plan centers on establishing six "safe areas" around the besieged cities of Sarajevo, Srebrenica, Zepa, Tuzla, Gorazde and Bihac. The U.N. promises protection, but with the whiff of appeasement in the air Bosnians hear a Western euphemism for refugee camps and capitulation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Apologies for D.A.R. Racism Never End
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As author of a study on civil rights protests at the Lincoln Memorial (Journal of American History, June 1993), I am writing about your May 18 article on the 1939 refusal by the Daughters of the American Revolution to allow Marian Anderson to sing in Constitution Hall. The personal biases and autocratic style of Fred E. Hand, the D.A.R. booking manager, do not justify a conclusion that the organization itself merely "acquiesced in an exclusionary policy." Hand was only the first tier of refusal; the D.A.R.'s highest officers promptly and explicitly affirmed the singer's rejection on racial grounds.

nytimes_articles.headline: Take My Players, Please, Harazin Says
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sweep was complete, and so the Astrodome scoreboard flashed the cartoon broom. Al Harazin, the general manager of the Mets, absorbed the indignity and adjourned to the clubhouse.   Staring at the floor after today's 5-4 defeat to the Astros, Harazin had a different sort of broom very much on his mind. A sweeping of the roster could begin within the week.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jessica R. Glass, Perry N. Fishkind
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jessica Rachel Glass, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, was married yesterday to Dr. Perry Neal Fishkind, a physician. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich officiated at the Hilton Hotel in Pearl River, N.Y.   Mrs. Fishkind, 25, received undergraduate and law degrees from Syracuse University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard R. Glass of Tenafly, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wynn Gets a Surprise: A Victory in 54 Holes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bob Wynn went to the driving range in anticipation of a playoff when he saw Bob Charles, considered by many golfers the real legend of Sleepy Hollow, hit his approach shot within 10 feet on the last hole of today's $550,000 Nynex Commemorative.   When Wynn heard a roar near the driving range of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club course, he figured that Charles had made the birdie putt and a playoff was about to get under way for the title Charles had won in 1988 and 1989 in record fashion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sara E. Barcan, Marc D. Draisen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sara Ellen Barcan, a master's degree candidate in city planning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was married yesterday to Marc Douglas Draisen, a Massachusetts State Representative from Boston. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Westfield, N.J.   Ms. Barcan, who is keeping her name, graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Barcan of Westfield. Her father is a senior partner at the law firm of Wilentz, Goldman & Spitzer in Woodbridge, N.J. Her mother, Bettye Barcan, is a reference librarian at the Springfield (N.J.) Public Library.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abigail H. Amsterdam, Daniel J. Bial
nytimes_articles.abstract: Abigail Holly Amsterdam, a manager in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's Office of Capital Program Management in New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Jeremy Bial, the founder and president of the Daniel Bial Literary Agency in New York. Rabbi Morrison Bial, the bridegroom's father, performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Summit, N.J.   Ms. Amsterdam, 30, is keeping her name. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and from which she received a master's degree in public policy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gunman's Acquittal Sends World a Message; Spirited Defense
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Gun Crazy," (editorial, May 25) you lambaste Lewis Unglesby, the lawyer who defended Rodney Peairs for shooting a Japanese exchange student, Yoshihiro Hattori. Mr. Unglesby argued that people have the right to answer the door carrying a firearm. "In his book," you state, anyone from ministers to Girl Scouts can be shot for ringing the doorbell.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Silence of Roxana Ramos
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the Indian summer days of last September, at a time when Roxana Ramos, a high school student here, became pregnant, an outreach worker for the local Planned Parenthood was sending stacks of letters to the public schools and Hispanic organizations of Nassau County.   The worker, Lori Rolleri, offered to broach subjects that were often difficult for immigrant families to tackle: sexuality and intimacy, sexually transmitted diseases, contraception and control over one's own body.

nytimes_articles.headline: Title German's First In Paris Since 1988 : Graf Dispels Fernandez's Upset Hopes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Other sports disburse their titles among all walks of life, blessing some of the most unlikely winners, but not women's tennis. . Mary Joe Fernandez, who on Saturday was trying to become the third such lowly seed to win a women's Grand Slam event in 26 ye

nytimes_articles.headline: Dr. Grunberger And Dr. Stang
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Arlene Richman Stang, a psychotherapist in New York and Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Lawrence Walter Nicholas Grunberger, a consulting physicist, editor and technical writer. Rabbi Judith Brazen officiated at the Plumbush Inn in Cold Spring, N.Y.    The bride graduated from Hunter College and received a master's degree in social work and a Ph.D. in clinical social work from New York University. She is a daughter of Mrs. Louis Richman of Great Neck and the late Mr. Richman. Her previous marriage ended in divorce.

nytimes_articles.headline: Amy R. Rothenberg, Michael E. Klein
nytimes_articles.abstract: Amy Rand Rothenberg, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Sylvan Glen Rothenberg of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Eliot Klein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Klein of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Morris S. Friedman officiated at the Fair Lawn (N.J.) Jewish Center.   Mrs. Klein is a teacher at the Rosa Parks School of Fine and Performing Arts in Paterson, N.J. She graduated from Syracuse University. Her father is a State Superior Court judge in Paterson.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bolivian Businessman Is Leading in the Election for President
nytimes_articles.abstract: A millionaire mining entrepreneur appeared to have come out ahead in Bolivia's presidential election today, receiving almost 38 percent of the vote, according to early and unofficial results.   For the entrepreneur, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, a similar outcome took place four years ago when he came out ahead in the popular vote in the presidential election only to lose out in the negotiations that characterize Bolivia's system of electoral politics.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Molding of Masako-san, Japan's Perfect Bride
nytimes_articles.abstract: In Japan this month, only those as dead and buried as the ancient emperors could miss these critical facts about Masako Owada: her favorite coffee-shop lunch is an $8 curry rice special, her Yorkshire terrier, Chocolat, was born in Scotland and joined the Owada family during a diplomatic mission to Paris, and the craftsmen who ruined her traditional Japanese kimono chests by covering the rich wood in tacky gold leaf are now very, very sorry.   For the casual channel-surfer or for anyone lingering in front of a subway newsstand these days, there is hardly a trivial detail you cannot learn about the savvy 29-year-old woman who on Wednesday will become the Crown Princess of Japan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Robin Shanus, Stephen Merkel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robin Shanus and Stephen Marcus Merkel, both lawyers, were married yesterday. Rabbi Lori Forman officiated at Wave Hill in the Bronx.   The bride is an associate in the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton. She graduated from the University of Rochester and received her law degree from Fordham University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Does Vitamin E Keep Hair From Graying?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your May 20 article on Vitamin E calls the new studies some of the first to find large-dose vitamin supplements beneficial. In 1958, Devin-Adair, my husband's company, published "90 Days to a Better Heart" by John Loughran. Chapter 16, "The Amazing Vitamin E," mentions Canadian doctors who found vitamin E beneficial in 80 percent of cases. Why are our doctors so reluctant to accept the value of vitamins, considering how many are removed from our processed foods? JOAN GARRITY  Pound Ridge, N.Y., May 25, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: Call New C.C.N.Y. President a Scholar and Skilled Politician
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your portrayal of Dr. Yolanda T. Moses, newly appointed president of City College (news article, May 25), reinforces gender- and race-based stereotypes that many of us in the academy are struggling to dismantle. I was dismayed by your value-laden slant, making Dr. Moses appear an affirmative action appointment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Sacrifice the Needy Workers
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration has agreed to shrink the proposed energy tax in order to push its economic plan through the Senate. That's an acceptable, though regrettable, compromise. But it's unacceptable that the Administration seems willing to make up for much of the lost revenue by cutting back its proposed tax credit for low-paid workers.    Such reneging would trash President Clinton's lofty pledge, repeated as recently as last week, that his budget would guarantee full-time workers enough money to bring their families out of poverty. Political compromises are fine, but not when they victimize America's poor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; From Adolf to Elvis, Fame and Its Many Faces
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Fame in the 20th Century" is a cruise through the waters of 20th-century celebrity under a wisecracking captain. Clive James, an Australian-born writer who has appeared on BBC television when he was not reviewing the medium for the British press, embarks on his droll eight-hour tour with the announcement that fame as we know it was invented in America in the 20th century.   As two hours' worth of clips from old newsreels and silent movies roll by in tonight's opener, you may suspect that the whole enterprise is merely a pretext for bringing on delicious glimpses of Queen Victoria and Enrico Caruso, Henry Ford and Thomas Alva Edison, Mahatma Gandhi and Mata Hari, Babe Ruth and Vladimir Ilyich Lenin (who, it is noted, attained divinity through a propaganda machine that Mr. James calls "the most successful thing in the Soviet Union except for the secret police").

nytimes_articles.headline: Karen Korngold, Michael Whaley
nytimes_articles.abstract: Karen Tessler Korngold, a daughter of Carole W. and Robert D. Korngold of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Michael Whaley, a son of William F. Whaley and Mrs. J. Lawson Kennedy, both of New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi Miriam Ancis performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel in New York.   Ms. Korngold, 29, is keeping her name. She is the director of project development at the Center for Montessori Teacher Education/NY in Scarsdale, which was founded and is directed by her mother. She graduated from Wesleyan University and received a master's degree in poetry from Columbia University. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Her father is president of the Manager, a marketing consulting firm in Scarsdale.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Rock; A Glimpse Of the Dead Of Old, With Sting
nytimes_articles.abstract: Over the years, the Grateful Dead's main musical problem in concert has been consistency: it can produce lapidary improvisational moments, only to join them with hours of swill. Only the faithful, there for the particularly Californian dream of transcendence the band sells for a living, can overlook the boredom and sluggishness the band has perfected.   At Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on a rainy Saturday night, at the first of two sold-out shows there, the Dead turned in what must be a rare thing, a whole three-hour concert that rarely flagged. The rhythm section meshed well, the singers, Jerry Garcia and Bob Weir, sang in tune and even harmonized without rough edges, and Mr. Garcia's improvisations, which can plod along at 15 miles an hour, actually hurried, as if he were trying to get somewhere. Mr. Garcia, who was hospitalized for exhaustion in August, has recently been on a regimen of exercise and a prescribed diet, and was looking fitter than he has in years.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: 1918: Lazy Husbands

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Another cross-cultural tale was told by a guest, SENATOR PATRICK J. LEAHY, the Vermont Democrat, who said he inherited his love of opera from his Italian immigrant grandfather who years ago encouraged him (or more accurately, required him) to listen to recordings by Caruso and other classical music on the radio.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW YORK CITY SMUGGLED TO NEW YORK: 7 DIE AS IMMIGRANT SHIP RUNS AGROUND   A tramp steamer smuggling hundreds of illegal Chinese immigrants into New York runs aground in a pounding surf off the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, ending a 17,000-mile odyssey from the Far East in a nightmare of panic, chaos, death and capture within sight of the golden door. At least 7 people are killed and 16 are seriously injured, officials say, as scores of terrified passengers leap into the sea and try to swim and wade ashore. A1. A TRIP BOTH DEVIOUS AND DESPERATE   The freighter that ran aground off Rockaway Peninsula is part of a recent surge of illegal Chinese immigrants who have made their way east to Hawaii, California, Guatemala, Florida and now, for what is believed to be the first time by boat, to the shores of New York. Why the immigrants chose a tortuous route around the Horn of Africa and into the North Atlantic is not clear. A1.

nytimes_articles.headline: SMUGGLED TO NEW YORK: The Scene; Waves of Panic Yield To Elation of Refugees
nytimes_articles.abstract: Some wore suits, maybe the best clothes they owned, as they leaped frantically into the dark, whitecapped water only 200 yards from America's shore. Perhaps it was a sign of high hopes in a new land. But there was likely no time to think as they surged to the deck when their ship ran aground, plunking one after another into the sea as they clutched all they owned in plastic bags.    When rescuers arrived, they found the surf off Rockaway Peninsula dotted with Chinese refugees in a desperate flailing dash to the beach. The air echoed with screams for help.

nytimes_articles.headline: High Spirits Dominate Gay Parade in Queens
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hundreds of gay and lesbian marchers coursed through Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday to demonstrate their political clout and celebrate a life style they say has recently been under attack in the borough and throughout New York City.   Taking to the streets of one of the city's most ethnically diverse neighborhoods, the marchers gathered for what organizers said was the borough's first gay pride parade. There were about 1,000 marchers and 500 spectators along the 15-block parade route, the police said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bruguera's French Is Better Than Courier's
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sergi Bruguera finally lived up to his reputation as a clay-court wizard by winning the 1993 French Open final today, defeating Jim Courier, the seemingly invincible two-time defending champion, in five arduous sets that were made even more oppressive by the steamy summer swelter that descended on Paris this afternoon.   Bruguera, Spain's most promising male tennis star since 60's great Manuel Santana, had hitherto been labeled an underachiever with a tendency to falter in the tough going. He had previously reached no Grand Slam finales and had a 4-7 record in five-set matches heading into today's confrontation with Courier, who had taken home four titles in five previous Slam finals.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: DR. CARLO M. CROCE of the Jefferson Cancer Institute in Philadelphia received the Charles S. Mott Prize for achievements in understanding the causes of cancer, specifically for identifying many of the cancer-causing genes involved in leukemias and lymphomas. And HIDESABURO HANAFUSA, Ph.D., of Rockefeller University in New York, won the Alfred P. Sloan Prize for basic scientific contributions to cancer research and work clarifying the relationship of viruses to oncogenes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: In North America, the 1993 Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest, played Friday evening, proved to be a triumph for Canada. In the first session, Friday night, the top score, of slightly more than 75 percent, went to Roland Brunet and Sarko Kassabian playing at the St. Rose Club in Fabreville, Quebec. They sat North-South, a slightly easier line in which to score. The East-West winners, with 71 percent, were Peter Gospodic and Jacques Cloutier of Guelph Ontario, playing in Cambridge, Ontario.   In the second session on Saturday, the North-South winners, with 74 percent, were Nicole Hainault and Normand Hubert, both from the Montreal area, playing at the West Hill Club in Montreal. The East-West winners, with 73 percent, were Robert Briselli of Broomall, Pa., and Steven Blomstedt of Westchester, Pa., playing at Lola's in Newton Square.

nytimes_articles.headline: Doctors, Spaghetti and My American Wife
nytimes_articles.abstract:
It was when I was lying on my back with my trousers and underpants around my knees, and a doctor was beginning, ominously, to don rubber gloves and advance purposefully that I first began to wonder whether it was all worthwhile.

In accordance with Government rules and procedures, I already had a vein punctured for an AIDS test. I had been duly pronounced H.I.V. negative and free of syphilis and infectious tuberculosis. Now I was about to undergo a minute visual examination for chancroids, apparently a symptom of sexually contagious diseases so terrible that neither I nor my friends had the faintest idea of what they were (save that the Oxford English Dictionary defined chancroids as "venereal ulcers").

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Like father, like son, or so its seems in Washington, where JESSE L. JACKSON Jr., the 28-year-old son of the black civil rights leader, has been appointed field director of the National Rainbow Coalition, the group his father established to join people of all races and colors in a fight for equality.   The younger Mr. Jackson, who received his law degree from the University of Illinois, will try to mobilize religious, labor, business, and governmental organizations in achieving the coalition's goals.

nytimes_articles.headline: Call New C.C.N.Y. President a Scholar and Skilled Politician; Record Distorted
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As the faculty members of the search committee that recommended Dr. Yolanda T. Moses, the president-designate of City College, we are deeply distressed by the unfair attacks to which she has been subjected and the gross distortion of her record, presented in your May 25 coverage of her appointment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hillsborough Journal; The Talk of the Isle (Pop. 6,000): Liberty or Death
nytimes_articles.abstract: In these times of blossoming multiculturalism, the tiny island of Carriacou has decided that self-respect demands that it too should join the struggle to say its piece.   For too long, residents say, they have been the silent victims of their administrative overlords in Grenada, or the "mainland," 20 miles to the south, and recently they have begun to insist that they be allowed to assert their own traditions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: "My Father Is a Tree"   Mark DeGarmo and Dancers St. Mark's Church    "My Father Is a Tree," declared the title of the new work that Mark DeGarmo and Dancers presented on Friday night as part of the Events series. Mr. DeGarmo explained in a program note that after his father died, a tree had been planted in his memory and that in his five-part dance he wished to explore themes of renewal and healing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Energy Tax Puts Senator In Tough Spot
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senator John B. Breaux once joked that his vote could not be bought but that "it can be rented."   That was during the Reagan era, when the Louisiana Democrat was a lowly backbench Congressman unabashedly seeking sugar subsidies for his farm constituents.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jill M. Birnbaum, Todd M. Orlich
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jill Michele Birnbaum, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin H. Birnbaum of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to Todd Michael Orlich, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David Orlich. Rabbi Daniel Fogel performed the ceremony at the Harbor Club in Huntington, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Experts Wavering on Steep Rise in Cigarette Tax
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton is eagerly eyeing a fat new tax on cigarettes, and for reasons easy to fathom. Tobacco addicts are a proven menace to themselves and others, so why not turn that to advantage, deterring their destructive behavior with high costs and using the revenue to offset the burden smokers add to the nation's health bill?   While the size of the tax is still being debated in the Administration, reports last week suggested that it could be as high as $2 a pack to help cover the cost of the health-care plan the President is preparing to submit to Congress later this year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Russians Fault U.S. on Shifting Ukraine's Arms
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a blunt expression of differences between Russia and the United States over policy toward nuclear weapons in Ukraine, the Russian Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, today criticized an American plan to place Ukraine's warheads under international control.   Speaking to reporters after a meeting with Defense Secretary Les Aspin in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, General Grachev said the nuclear warheads left in Ukraine after the breakup of the Soviet Union were Russian and should remain under Russian control.

nytimes_articles.headline: Age of 5 Can Be Like 65, So Strike the Gold Retires
nytimes_articles.abstract: Strike the Gold, who won the Kentucky Derby in 1991 and became a kind of racing folk hero as he lost his next 12 starts and then rebounded, was retired at the age of 5 yesterday with ruffles and flourishes for a career of 31 races, $3.4 million in purses and many late dashes through the homestretch.   "With the accumulating wear and tear over the years," said his trainer, Nick Zito, "it looks like Strike the Gold has run his last race. He made every dance. He just can't go on anymore."

nytimes_articles.headline: Bruguera Topples Courier to Capture French Crown
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I will tell you a secret," said Sergi Bruguera, a 22-year-old from Barcelona. "Every year since I was 6 years old, they asked me for a wish, and every year I wished to win at Roland Garros.". He was standing on a green-carpeted stage

nytimes_articles.headline: SMUGGLED TO NEW YORK: The Immigrants -- 7 Die as Crowded Immigrant Ship Grounds Off Queens; One Failed Voyage Illustrates Flow of Chinese Immigration
nytimes_articles.abstract: The freighter that ran aground off Rockaway Peninsula in Queens yesterday was part of a recent surge of illegal Chinese immigrants who have made their way to Hawaii, California, Guatemala, Florida and now, for what is believed to be the first time by boat, to the shores of New York.   Why the immigrants chose a tortuous route that took them around the Horn of Africa and north again into the cold waters of the North Atlantic is not clear, but officials said that a highly organized network of smugglers around the world probably provided assistance in stops along the way.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gunman's Acquittal Sends World a Message
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   It is the summer of 1987, and I am 16 years old. A high school student from South Carolina, I am living in Osaka, Japan, as a guest of the Goto family. Yoko, my host sister, decides to take me to a party at a friend's house. While we are there, I comment on a set of beautiful handmade masks lying on a table. Our host tells me her grandmother made them, and she asks which one I like best. A few hours later, when we are leaving, Yoko's friend gives me a handmade, padded silk bag. Inside is my favorite mask. The mask hangs on my wall at home now, a reminder of the warm welcome that strangers gave me wherever I went in Japan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pamela Schiller, Brian Socolow
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pamela Renee Lori Schiller, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon B. Schiller of Louisville, Ky., was married there yesterday to Brian Roy Socolow, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Socolow of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Slosberg officiated at Adeth Jeshurun Synagogue.    Mrs. Socolow, 27, is the media manager at the Elizabeth Arden Company in New York. She graduated from the University of Michigan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Marketing Is First to Enter This Ring
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the last couple of months, George Foreman and Tommy Morrison have been joined at the pocketbook, generating what promoters say will be boxing's richest pay-per-view fight.   But their unusual business relationship will change tonight about the time they touch gloves at the Thomas & Mack Center in Las Vegas, Nev., and come out fighting for the World Boxing Organization's vacant heavyweight championship. The pay-per-view telecast will begin at 9 P.M. Eastern time, with the 12-round bout expected to begin at about 10:30.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gina Lyn Ingber, Scott A. Mirskin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gina Lyn Ingber, a managing director of grants for Daytop Village Inc., the drug rehabilitation center in New York, was married yesterday to Scott Alan Mirskin, a director of sales at J & C International Seafood Inc., a seafood importer in Brooklyn. Rabbi Irving Goodman officiated at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N.Y.   Mrs. Ingber-Mirskin graduated from George Washington University and received an M.B.A. from Baruch College. She is a daughter of Mac Ingber of South Fallsburg, N.Y., and the late Rose C. Ingber. The bride is also a stepdaughter of Arline Ingber of South Fallsburgh.   Mr. Mirskin graduated from Buffalo State College. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mirskin of New Hyde Park, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alisa K. Lincoln, B. E. Lanckton
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alisa Kim Lincoln, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Jay Lincoln of Durham, N.H., was married yesterday to Benjamin Edward Lanckton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Van C. Lanckton of Newton, Mass. Rabbi David Mark performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Portsmouth, N.H.   Ms. Lincoln, 24, is keeping her name. She is a doctoral fellow in psychiatric epidemiology at Columbia University. She graduated from Tufts University and received a master's degree in public health from Boston University.

nytimes_articles.headline: BASKETBALL: Sports of The Times; Jordan Experiences The Discomfort Zone
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN a kind of comfort zone, Michael Jordan was stretched out on a couch in a hotel room in Cleveland three weeks ago with earphones on, quietly listening to music, and thinking. Thinking not so much of the Bulls' playoff game the next night, or of those many games ahead or the glorious games behind, but of his simple good fortune.   "Amazing how things have clicked so perfectly," he said then, "and how easily everything might have gone sour."

nytimes_articles.headline: Marsi Fein, Todd D. Miller
nytimes_articles.abstract: Martha Susan Fein, a daughter of Drs. Richard and Helen Fein of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Todd David Miller, a son of Harley Miller of Canton, Ohio, and the late Elaine Miller. Rabbi Avis Miller officiated at the Historic Car Barn, a catering hall in Washington.   Ms. Fein, 31, is keeping her name. She is known as Marsi. She is a public-policy researcher in the Office of Social Responsibility, the public-policy research arm of the Union Institute in Cincinnati. She graduated from Syracuse University, and she and her husband received master's degrees in public administration from New York University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Music; Dutch Opera in an Italian 'Ulysses'
nytimes_articles.abstract: In its unedited form, Monteverdi's "Return of Ulysses" looks at the Homeric tale of Ulysses's homecoming from a split perspective. Mostly, we see the story unfolding in mythologized but human terms. Yet there is also an otherworldly overlay, in which discussions between Jove and Neptune suggest the limits to which mortals determine their fates. This supernatural component, though extraneous to the narrative, resonates with the Prologue, in which Time, Fate and Love sing of their assaults on Human Mortality.   In the Netherlands Opera version of the work, the latest of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's imported productions, this heaven-and-earth symmetry is largely scuttled. The Prologue remains, but the gods have been banished except for Athene, the only Olympian to interact directly with Ulysses. One notable mortal, the nurse Euryclea, has also been jettisoned.

nytimes_articles.headline: Serbs Attack Two of U.N.'s 'Safe Areas' in Bosnia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bosnian Serb forces reportedly kept up their offensive against the United Nations-designated 'safe area' of Gorazde today and shelled another safe area, Srebrenica, defying a new United Nations Security Council resolution providing for troops to protect the six Bosnian Muslim areas.    Bosnian Serb commanders denied a five-member team of United Nations military observers access again today to Gorazde, where a year of fighting has trapped some 60,000 Muslims, said Comdr. Barry Frewer, spokesman for the United Nations force here.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Fund-Raising Frenzy, Cont'd.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two weeks ago, embarrassed White House officials canceled a breakfast with President Clinton that the Democratic National Committee had organized for lobbyists and other fat-cat contributors. Now they've pulled the plug on the committee's plan to establish a private foundation to help sell Mr. Clinton's health care program.   But other aspects of the D.N.C.'s dubious scheme are proceeding apace, making one wonder whether Bill Clinton's political friends were paying attention when he promised to run the special interests out of town.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Coattails Debated After Senate Loss in Texas
nytimes_articles.abstract: Has President Clinton become such a political pariah that he drove hordes of Texans to the polls on Saturday to vote for a Republican, Kay Bailey Hutchison, to the United States Senate?   Probably not. The Democratic incumbent, Senator Bob Krueger, had problems of his own, like being such a dreadful campaigner that his campaign produced television commercials extolling that fact. Besides, analysts warn against making too much of whether any President has "coattails" that significantly affect a local election for better or for worse.

nytimes_articles.headline: SMUGGLED TO NEW YORK: The Overview -- 7 Die as Crowded Immigrant Ship Grounds Off Queens; Chinese Aboard Are Seized for Illegal Entry
nytimes_articles.abstract: A tramp steamer smuggling hundreds of illegal Chinese immigrants into New York ran aground in moonlit darkness and a pounding surf off the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens early yesterday, ending a 17,000-mile odyssey from the Far East in a nightmare of panic, chaos, death and capture within sight of the golden door.   At least 7 people were killed and 16 were injured, officials said, as scores of terrified refugees leaped into the sea and tried to swim and wade ashore from the stricken 150-foot vessel, Golden Venture, her keel fast on a sandbar 200 yards off Jacob Riis Park.

nytimes_articles.headline: Knicks Off Bandstand, Bulls Feel Like Dancing
nytimes_articles.abstract: The message inside the cartoonlike bubble on the front of Scottie Pippen's hat, "!*?@#," held a sentiment that must have been left over from the last two weeks in the lives of the Chicago Bulls.   With the exception of Michael Jordan's continued public silence, any traces of angst seemed to have been replaced by a relaxed sense of anticipation as the Bulls prepared for the National Basketball Association finals against the Suns, with Game 1 Wednesday at Phoenix, and a chance to make history.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: U.N. Seeks Action in Somalia   The United Nations Security Council condemned the killing of 22 Pakistani peacekeepers in Somalia and called for prosecution. Officials placed the blame on a Somali warlord. Page A3. Spain's Socialists Squeak By    The Socialist Party of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez was returned to office in Spain, but it lost considerable ground to the conservatives. Page A8. Bruguera Wins French Open    Sergi Bruguera of Spain defeated Jim Courier, the two-time defending champion, in the French Open tennis final. SportsMonday, page C1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nelsa Gidney, Jordan Ringel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nelsa Gidney, the president of Gidney International, a television programming consulting company in New York, was married yesterday to Jordan E. Ringel, a lawyer. Rabbi Albert Thaler officiated at the home of Allan Albert, a friend of the couple, in New York.   Ms. Gidney, who is keeping her name, graduated from Northwestern University. She is the daughter of Ruth Wagner of Miami Beach, and the late Louis Gidney.

nytimes_articles.headline: House of a Different Color Is Shunned
nytimes_articles.abstract: Four years ago, Lee Jones climbed a ladder and started painting his house a light but distinct shade of purple in a cul-de-sac of beige and gray. It was an unusual color for English Hill, a development of two-story homes east of Seattle where a standard of esthetic fussiness is strictly enforced.    But mauve with deep purple trim -- combined with just a hint of teal around the windows -- became the new color of the Joneses' home, despite objections from the board that represents the development's homeowners. The family's defiant attempt to stay with their color combination set off a fight that went from the forested refuge of suburbia to King County Superior Court in Seattle.

nytimes_articles.headline: Patricia L. Eby and Peter A. Aldea
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Patricia Lynn Eby and Dr. Peter Andrew Aldea, plastic surgeons, were married yesterday at the Long Hill Estate in Beverly, Mass. Rabbi David Kudan officiated.   Dr. Eby, 36, is keeping her name. She is a chief resident in plastic and reconstructive surgery at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass. She graduated magna cum laude from Georgetown University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received her M.D. from Washington University in St. Louis. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald S. Eby of Gordonville, Pa.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kohl Faces Fierce Protests Over German Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the wake of new arson attacks aimed at Turks, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's appearance at the dedication of the newly renovated Berlin Cathedral brought heated protests today from demonstrators who accused him of not acting decisively against rightist violence.   The visit was Mr. Kohl's first public appearance since the arson attack that killed five Turkish women and girls in the western town of Solingen on May 29. He has been harshly criticized for not attending their funeral, the subsequent memorial service or the burial in Turkey.

nytimes_articles.headline: SMUGGLED TO NEW YORK: The Homeland; High Hopes, and Stakes, For China's Boat People
nytimes_articles.abstract: The desperate risks that Chinese boat people take to get to the United States, even jumping into the ocean to swim to shore, reflect the burden of the trust that has been placed in them by friends and family.   Very few Chinese can afford the thousands of dollars demanded by the "snakeheads," or smugglers. So those who yearn for a better life in the United States borrow from relatives, friends and even neighbors.

nytimes_articles.headline: Whitman Urges G.O.P. Unity After Vote
nytimes_articles.abstract: Christine Todd Whitman, considered the front-runner for the Republican nomination for governor, exhorted her supporters today not to slow a step until November, and called for Republicans to unify after Tuesday's primary and defeat the Democratic incumbent, Jim Florio.   "After June 8, all Republicans have to come back together," Mrs. Whitman told about 150 campaign workers at a get-out-the vote rally at the Flemington fairgrounds this afternoon. "This is going to be a tough battle all the way to Nov. 2."

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. ASKS ARRESTS OF SOMALIA KILLERS
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations Security Council today condemned the killing of 22 Pakistani peacekeeping soldiers in Somalia on Saturday and called for the "arrest and detention for prosecution, trial and punishment" of those responsible.   In a written report on the incident to the Council, United Nations peacekeeping officials pinned the blame squarely on Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, a Somali warlord who controls much of the capital, Mogadishu.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: DR. CARLO M. CROCE of the Jefferson Cancer Institute in Philadelphia received the Charles S. Mott Prize for achievements in understanding the causes of cancer, specifically for identifying many of the cancer-causing genes involved in leukemias and lymphomas. And HIDESABURO HANAFUSA, Ph.D., of Rockefeller University in New York, won the Alfred P. Sloan Prize for basic scientific contributions to cancer research and work clarifying the relationship of viruses to oncogenes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Armstrong Feels Like a Million Bucks
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lance Armstrong, the all-America bike rider, won $1 million today. More or less.   With a brash, in-your-face performance, the 21-year-old Texan, a professional only nine months, won the United States' richest one-day bicycle race, the $110,000 CoreStates United States professional championship.

nytimes_articles.headline: Essay; Cheer Up, Europe
nytimes_articles.abstract: Europe is entering the third millennium the same way it entered the second -- with the Christians kicking the Muslims out.   Many civilized Europeans are troubled by their New Barbarism. They are embarrassed at the way Turkish workers, denied citizenship, are being harassed in a Germany still arrogant about ethnic purity.

nytimes_articles.headline: Question: And Now Do Knicks Get Point?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The nature of professional sports is volatile, especially in New York. Moments after the Knicks were eliminated from the National Basktball Association playoffs by the Chicago Bulls on Friday night, people began voicing strong opinions about what had gone wrong.   The Knicks' major accomplishments -- a 60-victory season and an appearance in the Eastern Conference finals for the first time in 19 years -- did not ease the disappointment over the fact that the season ended sooner than the team and its fans had expected.

nytimes_articles.headline: First-Inning Hole Is Just Too Deep For Yankees
nytimes_articles.abstract: The hole was massive. Five Rangers had batted in the first, four had already scored and Melido Perez was dumbfounded on the mound. The Yankees rarely score runs for him. How were they going to save him from this 4-0 ditch?   It was a pertinent question and the answer was provided eight innings later because Perez's early disintegration proved too much for the Yankees to overcome. The Yankees picked and prodded at Kenny Rogers and Perez did calm down and pitch six shutout innings, but the offensive explosion in the first was enough to carry the Rangers to a 4-3 victory last night at Arlington Stadium.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "If I had said to my wonderful father, 'Daddy, I'd like to be a United States senator someday,' I know he would have patted me on the head and said, 'Kay, there are a lot of wonderful things you can do with your life, but that's probably not one of them.' " -- KAY BAILEY HUTCHISON, soon to be the seventh woman in the Senate.  [ A15:2. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Diana J. Lafer, Eric Mendelsohn
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Diana Joan Lafer, a daughter of Fred and Dr. Barbara Lafer of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Eric Janvrin Mendelsohn, the son of Louis and Kathleen Mendelsohn of Bloomfield, Conn. Rabbi Martin Freedman performed the ceremony at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.   The bride, 29, is a veterinarian in Simsbury, Conn. She graduated from Wesleyan University and received a doctor of veterinary medicine degree from Cornell University. Her father is a senior vice president and corporate secretary at Automatic Data Processing Inc., a payroll service company in Roseland, N.J. Her mother is a psychologist in Pompton Lakes, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Italians Reject Established Parties in Local Voting
nytimes_articles.abstract: In their first elections since the full extent of the country's huge bribery scandal became known, Italians swung away from their mainstream political leaders today and endorsed insurgent groups demanding political change.   While the ballot was restricted to the choice of mayors and local councils, some 10.5 million people -- more than a fifth of the electorate -- were eligible to vote under new rules affecting big cities from Milan in the North to Catania in Sicily. Over all, voters chose 1,000 local administrations.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abroad at Home; Bill Clinton's Center
nytimes_articles.abstract: With apologies to Art Buchwald, who had a similar dream in 1965 . . .    I awoke with a shudder the other morning from a terrible dream. I dreamt that George Bush had been re-elected last fall, and the country still had a President who was paralyzed by fear of the political right.

nytimes_articles.headline: Liza-Faith Cohn, William Wallach
nytimes_articles.abstract: Liza-Faith Michaelis Cohn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Linn Cohn of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to William David Wallach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick K. Wallach of Summit, N.J. Rabbi Jeshaia Schnitzer officiated at Temple Shomrei Emunah in Montclair, N.J.   The bride, 27, graduated with honors from Swarthmore College. She is a third-year law student at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. Her father is the senior partner of Cohn Lifland Pearlman Herrmann & Knopf, a law firm in Saddle Brook, N.J. Her mother, Sylvia J. Cohn, is special counsel to the firm.   Mr. Wallach, 30, is an associate at McCarter & English, a law firm in Newark. He graduated cum laude from Duke University and received a law degree from Washington University in St. Louis. His father is a lawyer with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A2-11  SURPRISE CHOICE IN GUATEMALA  In a surprise move, Guatemala's crusading human rights ombudsman, Ramiro de Leon Carpio, is sworn in as President. Politicians had considered him ineligible as unacceptable to the military.  A1  RUSSIA OPPOSES KIEV PLAN  Bluntly expressing Russian differences over policy toward Kiev, Defense Minister Pavel S. Grachev rebuffed an American plan to place Ukraine's nuclear warheads under international control.  A1

nytimes_articles.headline: An Influential Collector Of Modern Haitian Art
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Selden Rodman, a fledgling poet and American intelligence officer, disembarked for the first time in Haiti in 1944 to witness a performance of his recent play about the country's 19th-century revolution, the trip seemed little more than another colorful stop in a career deliberately conceived as a blend of art and adventure.   Instead of another simple port of call, however, the trip, paid for by the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs, placed Mr. Rodman in the country at just the right moment to witness the birth of modern Haitian painting.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1,550 Degrees at Staten Island
nytimes_articles.abstract: Former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro addressed the 17th annual commencement ceremony of the College of Staten Island yesterday.   More than 1,550 degrees were conferred by the school, which is a senior college of the City University of New York. It was the last ceremony on the Sunnyside campus. The school is moving to a new campus at the site of the old Willowbrook hospital next fall.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: SATURDAY Baseball  American League   KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Placed Keith Miller, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Craig Wilson, infielder, from Omaha of the American Association.   NEW YORK YANKEES -- Placed Mike Witt, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to June 2. Activated Steve Howe, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list.

nytimes_articles.headline: Haitian Advocate Slain in Brooklyn
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Brooklyn furniture store owner who was a prominent figure in New York's Haitian community was shot and killed late Saturday as he was getting into his car shortly after closing time, the police said.   The victim, Wilner Boucicault, 44, owner of A and B Furniture and Appliances in the East Flatbush section, was shot once in the chest, but he managed to drive his 1993 Mercedes-Benz several blocks before crashing into parked cars, said a police spokesman, Sgt. John McCluskey.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Karen Bernard   Dia Center for the Arts  155 Mercer Street  SoHo    Karen Bernard is a big, forthright woman with an interest in nontraditional dance movement and a gift for capturing the essence of a gesture. The program of new and recent work that she presented on Friday night was full of curious but potent little solos that made refreshing use of Ms. Bernard's size and authoritative presence.

nytimes_articles.headline: Woman in the News; From Demure Survivor to G.O.P. Star
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kay Bailey, one of seven women among the 236 graduates in the 1967 class at the University of Texas Law School, says she found herself shut out when she applied for work in the male-dominated world of Houston's law firms. On a whim, she went by KPRC-TV here one day to check into a reporting job.   The news director at the time, Ray Miller, impressed with both her assurance and her cheerfulness, hired Miss Bailey and sent her back to Austin, to cover the equally male-dominated world of the State Legislature.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Pop; A Blend of Celtic and Cajun
nytimes_articles.abstract: At Town Hall on Thursday night, Daniel Lanois talked about his family: the grandparents who sold the farm, a cousin reunited with the child she'd given up for adoption. The songs that went with the stories were also about heritage, a French-Canadian family tree that Mr. Lanois traces back to Celtic Brittany, down through Acadia and on south through New Orleans, where Cajun music meets African roots.   Mr. Lanois is best known as the producer for albums by U2, Peter Gabriel, Bob Dylan, the Neville Brothers and Robbie Robertson. He helps make their music, and his own, sound stately but open by combining old-fashioned effects -- a tremolo-strummed guitar, a touch of distortion -- with glimmers of the latest technology. On stage, he chose rawness. He played vintage Fender guitars through a Vox amplifier pushed to the edge of feedback, accompanied by Daryl Johnson on bass and Brian Blade on drums, whose mallets grew shredded during the set.

nytimes_articles.headline: Does Vitamin E Keep Hair From Graying?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Further to "Vitamin E Greatly Reduces Risk of Heart Disease, Studies Suggest" (front page, May 20):

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Manhattan Tap  Merkin Concert Hall    Manhattan Tap sailed into the airy, pleasant Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday for an evening of enjoyable tap-dancing. The most imaginative of the program's 11 dances, five of them New York or world premieres, was the new "Untitled," which the company's director, Heather Cornell, invited the audience to name. Choreographed by Ms. Cornell to a score by Keith Saunders, the group's pianist and music director, "Untitled" was a road race for four eager, conniving, exhausted runners seen ingeniously from the side and front. The hard-tapping runners were Ms. Cornell, Jeannie Hill, Lisa Hopkins and Max Pollak.

nytimes_articles.headline: 25 Years. The Vision of Robert Kennedy Lives On.
nytimes_articles.abstract: For many, in a society that seems always to crave new myths and new idols, Robert F. Kennedy is a rapidly fading memory a quarter-century after his death, brittle with age. For many others, the third of the nation that was not yet born when he was killed, there is no first-hand memory at all.   But to a remarkable number of Americans, Robert Kennedy remains a vivid presence, the archetype of the charismatic leader.

nytimes_articles.headline: Slaying Casts a Pall Over Prospect Park
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the Long Meadow of Prospect Park in Brooklyn, there are fresh flowers now in an old shoe box, a small American flag and crumpled bits of paper -- hand-written tributes to a popular drama teacher who was shot to death while fending off efforts to steal his bicycle last Wednesday.   Amid the park's 526 acres, the heartfelt mementos stand in isolation as a shrine at the spot where 42-year-old Allyn Winslow collapsed and died in a bed of clover.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Another cross-cultural tale was told by a guest, SENATOR PATRICK J. LEAHY, the Vermont Democrat, who said he inherited his love of opera from his Italian immigrant grandfather who years ago encouraged him (or more accurately, required him) to listen to recordings by Caruso and other classical music on the radio.

nytimes_articles.headline: ISRAEL ARRESTS 4 IN POLICE DEATH
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Israeli Shin Bet security service said today that it had arrested four Palestinians in the killing of an Israeli border policeman whose abduction and slaying prompted the deportation of about 400 accused Islamic militants to Lebanon in December.   The suspects, residents of Arab communities in and near Jerusalem, have confessed to the killing, Shin Bet said. They were identified as Mahmud Isa, 25, and Majed Abu Kteish, 23, both of Anata; Mahmud Atwan, 23, of Sur Bahir, and Musa Akari, 22 from Shuafat.

nytimes_articles.headline: Spanish Premier Re-elected, But Yields Ground to Right
nytimes_articles.abstract: After its toughest challenge since coming to power in 1982, the Socialist Party of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez was returned to office today in general elections but lost considerable ground to the conservative People's Party.   Projections by the Interior Ministry, based on 93 percent of the returns, gave the Socialists 159 seats in the 350-member lower house of Parliament against 141 seats for the People's Party, with the balance going to a leftist and to regional parties.

nytimes_articles.headline: Script Disapproval: Kings Complain, but Fault Lies With Actors
nytimes_articles.abstract: The scene of the Stanley Cup finals has changed, from Forum to Forum, but the script has stayed the same: The Los Angeles Kings play well, get the worst of a referee's decision, lose in overtime and complain.   That was the situation here Saturday night when the Kings lost to the Montreal Canadiens, 4-3. Montreal now holds a 2-1 lead in the four-of-seven-game championship round, which resumes here Monday night.

nytimes_articles.headline: Christian Right Splits G.O.P. in South
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Christian right is on the political move again in the South, pushing hard to win offices and influence in the Republican Party at a time when many of the party's national leaders are urging that it become more moderate and centrist.   Here in Richmond this weekend, Christian conservatives dominated the convention that nominated candidates to represent the party in this fall's elections for governor, lieutenant governor and attorney general.

nytimes_articles.headline: Apocalypso Now for American Team
nytimes_articles.abstract: There is no show in soccer quite as entertaining as Brazil nursing a lead, with little chance of losing it.   Ambitious and balletic, even on tired legs, Brazil toyed elegantly with the United States national team today at the Yale Bowl for a 2-0 victory in the opener of the U.S. Cup '93. The Americans had a couple of opportunities, but really had no clue. How do you interrupt a performance like this? How many more years will it take to learn the art form?

nytimes_articles.headline: IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: 1943: Parity of Pay

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Friendship's Lyricism, On Stage and in Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: Everyone seemed a friend of the entire human race at "Dancers and Friends 2," the second annual benefit for Friends in Deed on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater. Friends in Deed, an organization founded in 1991, is dedicated to providing support to people affected by life-threatening illnesses, primarily AIDS and cancer. It was therefore appropriate that friendship was often a theme of this program, in which a remarkable array of ballet and modern dancers took part.   Alessandra Ferri and Julio Bocca, of American Ballet Theater, got on wonderfully together in George Balanchine's lighthearted "Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux," which they danced with ebullient bravura.

nytimes_articles.headline: PULSE: New York City Water Supply
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City reservoir system's 1992-93 "water year" - the 12-month cycle on which official water-supply statistics are based - ended on May 31. The cycle follows natural seasonal fluctuations in water levels, which peak in May.    Readings were moderately below normal for the first six months, but rose considerably after heavy precipitation in January and March. A final surge came from a typically rainy April and heavy spring runoff in the watershed area.    Readings for 1992-93, shows by the dotted black line, are compared with normal levels (solid gray line), and with last year (dashed gray line), when reservoirs neared drought level.    Figures are for the Delaware, Catskill and Croton reservoir systems, whichsupply water to New York City and most of WEstchester County. Distribution reservoirs (Kensico, Hillview, Jerome Park and Central Park) are not included.

nytimes_articles.headline: Belmont Seeks Clues But Finds Only Fate
nytimes_articles.abstract: Colonial Affair and the other long-shot stars of the 1993 Belmont Stakes headed into the second half of the racing season with newly won stature yesterday. But the racing world was still groping for reasons, and finding none, for the fatal breakdown of the reigning 3-year-old, Prairie Bayou.   The weather was drizzly and the surface of the track at Belmont Park was getting heavy when Prairie Bayou buckled in the backstretch about half a mile into the race Saturday. His jockey, Mike Smith, jumped over the horse's right side and escaped injury. But Prairie Bayou, who had run second in the Kentucky Derby and first in the Preakness, suffered compound fractures in his left foreleg and was destroyed by injection about 30 minutes later.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart on Wednesday with an article about proposed energy taxes described two elements of the plan incorrectly. As passed by the House, the plan would tax liquefied petroleum gas at 26.8 cents per million British Thermal Units, not 61.0 cents, and would impose a natural gas tax on consumers, not utilities.    The related article referred to an economist incorrectly. He is Philip Verleger.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Spider Woman' and 'Angels' Win Top Honors in Tony Awards
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Kiss of the Spider Woman," the musical adaptation of Manuel Puig's novel about a gay window dresser and a straight Marxist guerrilla who are imprisoned together in a Latin American jail, was the big winner at the Tony Awards presentation last night, with seven awards, including best musical of the 1992-93 season.   "Angels in America: Millennium Approaches," the first installment of Tony Kushner's two-play epic that uses AIDS as a metaphor for a national spiritual decline in the 1980's, won four awards, including best play, best director of a play, and best leading actor and featured actor in a play.

nytimes_articles.headline: Trenton Acts to Loosen Industrial Cleanup Law
nytimes_articles.abstract: Confronting a precipitous loss of industrial jobs, New Jersey is preparing to weaken environmental cleanup rules for land intended for industrial or commercial use.   Although environmentalists are worried that the proposal will set a bad precedent, urban planners are applauding it, saying it would address a problem that exists to varying degrees across the country: urban land lying fallow, in part because of the costs of cleaning up pollution.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editorial Notebook; Germany Is Not to Blame for Bosnia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hawks and doves disagree passionately over whether the West should intervene militarily to stop the slaughter in the Balkans. But almost everyone is too ready to agree on a key issue of historical responsibility.    It is now conventional wisdom that Germany, by extending diplomatic recognition to Croatia and Slovenia in late December 1991, forced the breakup of the old Yugoslav federation, making the subsequent tragedy in Bosnia inevitable. That's a strained reading of the chronological record. Worse, it conceals the real dynamics of the crisis, inviting future policy mistakes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ellen S. Levy, Merrill Halpern
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ellen Sue Levy, a sales representative and executive assistant at the American Jewish Congress in New York, was married yesterday to Merrill Bennett Halpern, a vice president at Citibank in Stamford, Conn. Cantor Henry Weintraub performed the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.   Mrs. Halpern, 32, graduated magna cum laude from Barnard College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She is the daughter of Bernice Levy of New York and the late Sheldon S. Levy, who was an acting justice of the New York State Supreme Court.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reporter's Notebook; Amid Motions, Delays and Gawkers, Altman Trial Drags On at Painful Pace
nytimes_articles.abstract: Most trials develop a certain rhythm, but so far there have been decidedly more ebbs than flows in the fraud and bribery trial of Robert A. Altman.   During the last two weeks the pace of Mr. Altman's trial slowed to a crawl, bogged down in contentions by defense lawyers that prosecutors had failed to reveal in a timely fashion material that would have been favorable to Mr. Altman.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cambodian Prince Pits Sons Against Each Other in Bid for Power
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prince Norodom Sihanouk turned old family divisions into a weapon today in his campaign to return to power in Cambodia, pitting one of his sons against the other in hopes of forging a coalition government.   Although diplomats and United Nations peacekeepers say they believe that the Prince will eventually succeed in pulling together a coalition, the political climate of this war-shattered nation has been poisoned by feuding within the royal family.

nytimes_articles.headline: Protection of Region's Open Spaces Urged by Planning Group
nytimes_articles.abstract: The planning group that more than half a century ago proposed the system of parkways that today unites the New York region has concluded that it is now critically important to identify and protect broad corridors of woods, open space and sparse development that still survive 40 to 100 miles from New York City.   The group, the Regional Plan Association, said that vast expanses of open space, previously considered invulnerable, are now threatened. A decade of frenetic development has claimed farmland, forests and verdant private estates from northern Connecticut to southern New Jersey, it said.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: The guard at the State Department changed yesterday when RICHARD BOUCHER, the bearded and unflappable press secretary whose soft but authoritative voice and skill at obfuscation were well known to diplomatic reporters, stepped aside in favor of MIKE McCURRY. Mr. McCurry is a veteran press secretary, whose expertise lies in political campaigns more than in international affairs.    He served as spokesman for three candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination: Senator John Glenn (1984), Bruce Babbitt (1988), now the Interior Secretary, and Senator Bob Kerrey (1992). He is also a former spokesman for the Democratic National Committee.

nytimes_articles.headline: Following A Mouse Through History
nytimes_articles.abstract: A COMPUTER can teach you about computers. Computerworks, a program from the Software Marketing Corporation of Phoenix, offers a colorful and lively series of on-screen lessons.   Most of each screen is taken up by a picture of the component being studied. Along the top is a Windows-style menu bar (the DOS program can work under but does not require Windows) and along the bottom are two rows of icons, 16 in all, standing for the available choices: computer systems, display systems, disk drives and storage (memory would better have been called the less anthropomorphic storage, but it is too late now), printers and plotters, keyboards and input devices, circuit boards and electronic components, software, peripherals and cables, history of computers, as well as buttons to reach the index, related topics, a notepad, lessons and quizzes, and to print, get help or quit.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Rush the Choice of a School Chief
nytimes_articles.abstract: In three more weeks, New York City will be without a Schools Chancellor. Joseph Fernandez, who assumed the post in January 1990, will not serve beyond June 30. Earlier this year the Board of Education voted 4 to 3 not to renew his contract.    The board now seems determined to choose Mr. Fernandez's successor by the time he leaves. That's desirable, but may not be realistic. Meeting an arbitrary deadline should not take precedence over choosing the right candidate.

nytimes_articles.headline: Adirondack Survival Waits for State Senate
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The Adirondack Forest -- part of the heritage of New York State and the United States as priceless as the Statue of Liberty -- is in danger, unless the State Legislature acts promptly. Money to preserve the Adirondacks is available, in unclaimed bottle deposits and existing taxes, but the State Senate has to approve legislation to earmark this money for an environmental trust fund. The legislation has been approved by the Assembly and is strongly supported by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

nytimes_articles.headline: Senate Repeals No-Fault Insurance Law
nytimes_articles.abstract: The state Senate gave final legislative approval tonight to a repeal of Connecticut's 20-year-old no-fault automobile insurance law, which critics say has led, despite the statute's intent, to higher premiums and clogged courts.   The repeal measure -- which still requires approval from Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who has not said whether he will sign it -- would replace no-fault insurance with a modified tort system that proponents said could cut premiums on a basic automobile insurance policy by more than 19 percent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mercado 2-Hitter Gives Monroe P.S.A.L. Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Move over, Hank Greenberg. Move over, Ed Kranepool. Make room for 18-year-old Ulises Mercado in the baseball annals of James Monroe High School.   The 5-foot-6-inch, 135-pound senior right-hander pitched a two-hit shutout against Franklin Delano Roosevelt High of Brooklyn yesterday at Yankee Stadium to give the Bronx school its first Public Schools Athletic League championship in 24 years. The score was 4-0.

nytimes_articles.headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lord Young, executive chairman of Cable & Wireless PLC and former government trade minister, is reading Thomas Mann's "Joseph and His Brothers." ."It is probably the best book I have ever read. It is terribly long and I tend to like

nytimes_articles.headline: A New York Cabaret Diva Is Storming Hollywood
nytimes_articles.abstract: Every Sunday evening, the limos and sports cars line up along a bleak stretch of Hollywood for an evening with Jenifer Lewis of "The Diva Is Dismissed."   "Divas are usually rich, famous and disgusting," said Ms. Lewis. "I was a poor diva. A diva is someone who pretends to know who they are and look fabulous doing it! That was me."

nytimes_articles.headline: Web of Scandal: A special report.; Neither Votes Nor Candor Lighten the Pall Over Italy
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is now almost a year and a half since Italy's corruption scandal erupted, and hundreds of prominent executives and politicians have been humiliated or ruined by the revelations.    Not only has the scandal touched virtually every political party and corporation; it has also demonstrated the hollowness of Italy's economy, where hundreds of millions of dollars -- some say billions -- have been wasted in payoffs and other bribes.  The Political Damage    As local elections showed on Sunday, the damage wrought to the established parties has redefined Italy's political geography.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bearing Witness : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Adults Around the World Are Furious About This" (May 26) by Michael Kelly: .Mr. Kelly fails to see that Hillary Rodham Clinton and her generation, at their best and deepest, are on a religious quest. The Christian tradition calls o

nytimes_articles.headline: ESPN Going Into Overtime
nytimes_articles.abstract: ESPN yesterday unveiled ESPN2, a 24-hour sports network that will go on the air Nov. 2 and will offer a mixture of news and information, live events and programming aimed at viewers between the ages of 18 and 34. ESPN appeals mainly to the 25-54 age group.   ESPN2 will show up to three nights a week of National Hockey League games, and will feature college basketball, arena football, volleyball and extreme sports like sky-surfing. The cornerstone program will be SportsNight, a news and highlights show to air Friday-Monday, from 8-11 P.M.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nigeria Nervously Awaits Vote to End Army Rule
nytimes_articles.abstract: By the laws of political logic, this should be a time of euphoria in Nigeria as the military appears poised to hand power to civilians. But as Saturday's multi-party presidential elections draw near, attention has shifted to the broken promises, corruption and economic mismanagement of the military leaders.   There is "a lot of skepticism and disbelief" about whether the military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, is genuinely prepared to go, said Gen. Olusegun Obansanjo, a former head of state and the only Nigerian military leader to yield power to civilians voluntarily.

nytimes_articles.headline: Weighing Milky Way, Astronomers Find Halo of Dark Matter
nytimes_articles.abstract: The serenity of the Milky Way in the night sky masks the appetite of a cannibal. That cannibalism provides an important clue to the extent and nature, if not the identity, of the mysterious invisible matter that dominates the universe.    The clue is that a vast halo encompassing the Milky Way galaxy contains 10 times the mass that astronomers can see in the multitude of visible stars. Astronomers said this was the most important estimate yet of the amount of invisible matter in a single galaxy, and proof of the existence of what is known as dark matter.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893 :Zola's Locomotion : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: Paris -A striking feature of social life at present is the popularity of the bicycle both as a means of locomotion and as amusement. It is used by members of both sexes, of all classes of society and of all professions. Even M. Emile Zola, who lives lik

nytimes_articles.headline: Poll Finds Knowledge About AIDS Increasing
nytimes_articles.abstract: AMERICANS show improved knowledge about AIDS as well as increased personal acquaintance with victims of AIDS, and half of all adults now say they have acted to avoid getting AIDS themselves, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   Forty-nine percent of the 1,347 adults interviewed June 1 to 3 answered "yes" when asked, "Is there anything in particular you have done to avoid getting AIDS?" The nationwide telephone poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Doctor Fashions Building Block. Again.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Doc Gooden stood before his locker and said the words almost sheepishly. He knew he was being repetitive. He knew everyone had heard it before. Still, he couldn't help hoping. One day, he figures, it has to come true.   "I probably sound like a broken record saying this," Gooden acknowledged last night at Shea Stadium, "but, hopefully, we can build on this."

nytimes_articles.headline: Power Authority, Facing New Fines, Dismisses Its President
nytimes_articles.abstract: After years of poor performance at its nuclear plants, the New York Power Authority today dismissed its president and chief operating officer.   The authority announced that John C. Brons, its president since March 1991, would resign immediately and would be replaced for the time being by Robert G. Schenberger, who had been executive vice president for finance and administration.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nets' Petrovic Dies in Auto Accident in Germany
nytimes_articles.abstract: Drazen Petrovic, the New Jersey Nets' 28-year-old guard and the team's leading scorer, was killed yesterday in an automobile accident in Germany, according to his father.   Reached by telephone at his home in Croatia, Jole Petrovic confirmed reports of his son's death, saying, "It is true."

nytimes_articles.headline: Justices Allow Religious Groups After-Hours Use of Public Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that public school systems that open their schools to after-hours use by community groups must permit religious groups to use the buildings on the same terms.   The 9-to-0 decision in a case from Long Island had the effect of overturning a New York State law that state courts and education officials had long interpreted as barring the use of school property for any religious purpose.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of a computer malfunction, a review in Weekend on Friday about "Latin American Artists of the 20th Century," at the Museum of Modern Art through Sept. 7, rendered the names of four artists incorrectly. They are Matta, Joaquin Torres-Garcia, Rufino Tamayo and Carlos Merida.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Mr. Allen has demonstrated no parenting skills that would qualify him as an adequate custodian for Moses, Dylan or Satchel. His financial contributions to the children's support, his willingness to read to them, to tell them stories, to buy them presents and to oversee their breakfasts, do not compensate for his absence as a meaningful source of guidance and caring in their lives." -- ACTING JUSTICE ELLIOTT WILK.  [ B4:3. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Italian Pianist Awarded Top Prize In Cliburn Contest
nytimes_articles.abstract: From the outset of the Ninth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition two and a half weeks ago, many have called it the year of the Italians, and they were right. It is the year of one Italian, at least: Simone Pedroni, from Novara, who took first prize at the awards ceremony on Sunday evening at the Tarrant County Convention Center Theater here. Valery Kuleshov of Russia finished in second place and Christopher Taylor of the United States was third.   Mr. Pedroni received a gold medal, a silver cup and a $15,000 cash prize. Along with Mr. Kuleshov and Mr. Taylor, he will be given concert tours and career management for the next two seasons and a Philips recording. Mr. Pedroni also won the Steven de Groote Memorial Chamber Music Award of $1,000 for his performance of the Franck Piano Quintet with the American String Quartet. On Succeeding Horowitz    Mr. Pedroni's concerts are to include a debut recital in Carnegie Hall at a date to be determined. "It will be one of the most beautiful experiences of my life," he said through an interpreter. "One of the first records I ever bought was Horowitz at Carnegie Hall. I never thought I would succeed him there."

nytimes_articles.headline: What Makes Energy Tax Scary; It Will Create Jobs
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   There are at least two aspects of the energy, or British Thermal Unit, tax that seem to be missing in the debates on the subject:   (1) The tax will create jobs, rather than lose them and will not necessarily lead to inflation because, as it becomes economically disadvantageous to waste energy, we will insulate our homes better. Then, reduced energy consumption will reduce pollution and the needs for extensive and expensive emission controls. Also, we will build, rather than merely talk about, high-speed rail lines in high-density traffic corridors. Insulating homes, building tracks and railroad cars will provide new jobs. Jobs come and go: we now produce very few horse-drawn carriages, full-fashioned stockings or vacuum tubes.

nytimes_articles.headline: 90's Minimalism Clashes With Ancient Rome
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Sir Norman Foster, the British architect, flew to the south of France a decade ago, he had one overriding question on his mind: What design would coexist with a Roman temple he saw as "one of the most beautiful buildings in the world"?    His answer, in glass and steel, is ready. Sir Norman's cultural center in Nimes is remarkable if only because it faces one of the world's oldest surviving Roman temples, among the most graceful of its kind. The architect insists on talking about the temple because, he says, it was this sanctuary, built by Agrippa, the Roman military leader and statesman, a few years before Jesus' birth, that determined the shape of his modern building.

nytimes_articles.headline: Striking Coal Miners Fight To Protect Shrinking Power
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was just before midnight, an hour very dark and still in the mountains south of Charleston, and a dozen men were gathered around a fire on the picket line at the Hobet 21 Mine.   The strike by the United Mine Workers of America was in its third week, and a certain domesticity had settled in: The men had built a sturdy picket shack and stocked it with food and drink. They had adopted a stray dog and named it Striker. They had become enough of a fixture along U.S. 119 that motorists honked their horns, and many stopped with firewood and food.

nytimes_articles.headline: Altman Film in Festival
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robert Altman's "Short Cuts" will be the opening-night film of the 31st New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center has announced. The festival opens on Oct. 1 and will run through Oct. 17. The film, based on the short stories of Raymond Carver, has 22 principal roles. The cast includes Anne Archer, Bruce Davison, Robert Downey Jr., Peter Gallagher, Buck Henry, Jack Lemmon, Frances McDormand, Matthew Modine, Tim Robbins, Madeline Stowe, Lily Tomlin and Tom Waits.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.C.L.A. Hunger Strike Ends
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ending a two-week hunger strike, nine protesters at the University of California at Los Angeles today reached a compromise with administrators to strengthen the campus's Chicano studies program. The new program will give the 20-year-old Chicano studies program more of the trappings of an academic department.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's a Soft Sell Amid High Hopes
nytimes_articles.abstract: They want at least $500 million but won't say so boldly. Not anymore. But Atlanta Olympic organizers believe that network TV rights for the 1996 Summer Olympics are worth what Billy Payne, the president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, brashly said they were last year.   But now they're trying a softer sell, which they hope will lead to the same conclusion.
