Top committee officials -- minus Payne, who has just returned to work after recent heart-bypass surgery -- were in Manhattan last week to convince ABC, NBC and CBS of the value to be gained by paying 25 percent more for Atlanta than the $401 million NBC paid for the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Talk of the Tonys; After the Tonys, Some Fault Is Found, But Tickets Sell
nytimes_articles.abstract: Almost everyone was happy, though maybe not happy enough.   In the aftermath of Sunday night's Tony Awards, the grumbling was minimal, but it was there. Some of the winners were a little irritated at the 30-second limit on acceptance speeches and the swelling strings that drowned them out as they outstayed their welcome. It was, as Tony Kushner, author of the Tony-winning "Angels in America," said on the air, "a scary orchestra."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Victor in Spain Has New Hurdles Ahead
nytimes_articles.abstract: With the domestic economy in a slump, the governing Socialist Party muddied by corruption scandals and the electorate tired of the same old faces in power, Spain's conservative opposition seemed to have everything going for it in general elections on Sunday.   But in the end, emerging from the seclusion of the Moncloa Palace, apologizing for past mistakes and single-handedly carrying his party's flag, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez again showed his ability to charm Spanish voters by winning his fourth successive general election.

nytimes_articles.headline: Latest Resume Entry: Brown to Coach Pacers
nytimes_articles.abstract: LARRY BROWN was named coach of the Indiana Pacers yesterday, succeeding the dismissed BOB HILL.   It will be the fifth National Basketball Association coaching assignment for Brown, who recently quit as coach of the Los Angeles Clippers. He also coached at U.C.L.A. and Kansas as well as in the American Basketball Association.

nytimes_articles.headline: Making Fishing Easier For All Kinds of Anglers
nytimes_articles.abstract: AFTER his father was in a serious accident nearly a decade ago, Chris Marino got to thinking about how he would handle it if he were ever incapacitated. He spends a lot of time mulling such matters, working nights loading U.P.S. trucks. And he decided that one of the things he would miss most would be fishing.   Since he was a boy, he has fished with friends in nearby Spy Pond, where bodies were supposedly dumped during the Revolutionary War. For him, a driver's license meant the freedom to fish all over the massive Croton Reservoir. When he married, he and his wife, Christine, went on a honeymoon fishing trip.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Historic Captain . . .
nytimes_articles.abstract: PAUL INCE became the first black player to be named captain of the English national team yesterday, and his first game with his new responsibility is tomorrow night, against the United States in a U.S. Cup '93 match in Boston.   Ince, a 25-year-old midfielder for Manchester United, was picked by Coach GRAHAM TAYLOR to replace DAVID PLATT, who was hurt on Sunday playing for Juventus of Turin in the Italian League.

nytimes_articles.headline: Senators See Compromises As Talks Begin on Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton met this evening with the two leading Democratic Senators on tax and budget matters, the start of a two-week sprint to win Senate committee approval of his tax and spending plans.   Afterward, the Senators -- George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, chairman of the Finance Committee -- and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen predicted that the negotiations would lead to legislation encompassing the basic elements of the President's proposals.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hungary Party Ousting Four Leading Rightists
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hungary's governing party has disassociated itself from the small but vocal right-wing circle that has coalesced around Istvan Csurka, one of the party's leaders. The action followed months of indecision on how to handle the party's internal right-wing opposition.   The steering committee of the Democratic Forum recommended this weekend that the party's ethics committee should expel Mr. Csurka and three right-wing colleagues.

nytimes_articles.headline: World Health Official Says AIDS Spread Could Be Controlled
nytimes_articles.abstract: The AIDS epidemic that is galloping through much of the world could be curtailed if known preventions measures were more widely applied and if an additional $1.5 billion to $2.9 billion a year were spent in developing countries on AIDS prevention, a World Health Organization official said here today at the ninth international AIDS meeting.   The extra money would represent an increase of about 1.5 percent over current health-care budgets in developing countries and would translate into the cost of one soft drink for every person in the world, said Dr. Michael H. Merson, who heads the W.H.O. program on AIDS.

nytimes_articles.headline: PLEADING FOR LIFE, STUDENT IS SLAIN
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 16-year-old student on a lunch hour stroll outside a Brooklyn school for troubled teen-agers was chased by two older youths, cornered between two parked cars and shot several times at close range yesterday as he pleaded for his life, the police said. He died on the street minutes later.   New York City police detectives said that at least two assailants had pursued the student through the streets after a dispute earlier in the lunch hour that appeared to focus on a leather jacket or vest.

nytimes_articles.headline: Overtime Still No Time for Kings as Canadiens Take 3-1 Lead
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Montreal Canadiens continued their domination of playoff overtime tonight and they are now one victory away from their 24th Stanley Cup championship.   John LeClair scored for Montreal at 14 minutes 37 seconds of the extra session to clinch a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Kings at the Forum. The Canadiens can clinch the series Wednesday night at home in Game 5.

nytimes_articles.headline: Settlement In Lawsuit On Job Bias
nytimes_articles.abstract: Accused of using reverse discrimination to diversify the municipal work force, the Dinkins administration agreed yesterday to give raises and higher ranks to about 75 supervisors at the Human Resources Administration who contended that they were passed over for advancement because they were white.   The administration did not acknowledge wrongdoing in settling a lawsuit brought in March by the Social Service Employees Union, Local 371, which charged that top officials manipulated city rules to promote black and Hispanic supervisors who did not perform as well as whites on Civil Service tests.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bearing Witness : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Reading Michael Kelly's articles about Mrs. Clinton (May 25- 26), I had two misgivings. First, I was unable to square her lamentations about deviant behavior with her support for abortion and homosexuality. Second, Mrs. Clinton has been appointed to refo

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943 :Attacks in Italy : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA - [From our New York edition:] Tearing apart the Axis air opposition at the rate of 19 enemy planes destroyed to one allied craft lost, squadrons of Allied bombers kept the Italian islands and Italy itself under "a

nytimes_articles.headline: In an Instant, Glitter of 3-Year-Old Class Is Gone
nytimes_articles.abstract: Patrice Smith watched her husband riding Prairie Bayou down the backstretch for the last time in the Belmont Stakes the other day, and when the colt broke down she realized that Mike Smith had just lost something along with everybody else. "The horse," she reasoned, "was his ticket to greatness."   Prairie Bayou was a lot of people's ticket to greatness.

nytimes_articles.headline: Babbling Brooks and Talking Dogs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Advertising executives are reeling over the sheer ingenuity of the proposal by Space Marketing Inc. to orbit mile-wide billboards that would send corporate logos gliding across starry skies from Tokyo to the Tampa Bay. Advertising Age called it "the most ambitious marketing endeavor ever contemplated." But competitors of the Roswell, Ga., agency have not been caught napping, and many are thinking big when it comes to exploiting overlooked venues in the natural world. Among the more innovative proposals:   Bird-belly billboards. "There are billions of birds in the world," says Nathan Tarr of Birdvertising Corporation, "and virtually all of them have dishwater-dull bellies." Mr. Tarr is out to change that, by placing ads on what he calls "millions of square feet of non-utilized feather space." He's starting with a small project involving the release of 300 doves bearing tiny Gucci emblem's on their undersides. If that goes well, flocks of migrating geese will soon sport the Eddie Bauer logo.  Fish flank signs. Researchers at Silurian Systems in Tacoma, Wash., are seeking ways to genetically engineer fish so that corporate emblems will appear just behind the gills. A company spokesman said, "With a bit of genetic tweaking, your next piece of Dover sole could display a brief, tasteful message such as, "How about a chocolate mousse for dessert?" Adfish planned for released into the environment include steelhead trout bearing the Bud Light logo.

nytimes_articles.headline: What Makes Energy Tax Scary
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "A Bipartisan Disservice" (editorial, May 21), on the proposals by Senators David Boren, Oklahoma Democrat, and John Danforth, Missouri Republican, to cut taxes and spending from President Clinton's proposed budget, was not clearly thought out where you touch on the Administration's plan to tax energy by British Thermal Units used.   You maintain that the Clinton-backed energy tax hurts oil-producing states like Oklahoma and Louisiana, and that the Boren-Danforth approach would shift the burden from South to North.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-15  IN ITALY, A WEB OF SCANDAL  The corruption scandal in Italy suggests that its emergence as an industrial power was composed in part on the myth that an economic boom was built on free enterprise rather than on an unholy alliance that denied the notion of competition.  A1  U.N. RAISES FIREPOWER IN SOMALIA  The United Nations command in the Somali capital increased its firepower there and warned a faction leader that it would punish those responsible for killing about two dozen Pakistani peacekeepers.  A1

nytimes_articles.headline: When Americans Are No Longer No. 1
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "New Tally of World's Economies Catapults China Into Third Place" (front page, May 20): In proposing to abandon measuring the size of national economies by current exchange rates in preference for purchasing power equivalents, the International Monetary Fund replaces one imperfect method with another.

nytimes_articles.headline: City Hall Can't Brag About Water Practices
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Money Down the Drain" (Op-Ed, May 21), Timothy D. Searchinger would have us believe that Mayor David N. Dinkins and New York City's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, Albert F. Appleton, are secret environmentalists out to save clean water and city money. Their newfound interest in low-flow toilets, shower heads and leaky faucets, while greatly needed and long overdue, is really part of a much larger city effort, more about raising money than saving it. Their misguided and ill-planned effort to meter the city's water use has created havoc and hardship in all five boroughs.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Moves Troops to Somali City And Vows Punishment for Attack
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations command increased its firepower in Mogadishu today and warned a Somali factional leader that it would punish those responsible for killing about two dozen Pakistani peacekeepers in attacks on Saturday.   Adm. Jonathan Howe, the special United Nations envoy to Somalia, said on United Nations radio, "A full investigation will be made into the affair, and appropriate steps will be taken against those responsible."

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Flu Drugs Work In Tests on Animals
nytimes_articles.abstract: JUST as scientists have identified the flu strain that they expect will fell Americans next year, a group of Australian researchers has offered a glimpse of hope for the future. They have designed two new drugs that in animals can protect against influenza if given early and can shorten the course of the disease if given after symptoms appear.    Scientists caution that much work must done before it is known whether the drugs will benefit peoople. And there is no guarantee that the ever-changeable influenza viruses will not develop resistance to them. But, the researchers say, the drugs' discovery shows at the very least that it is possible to find new drugs by rationally designing them to block key viral proteins.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: D'AMATO CONSIDERS RUN FOR GOVERNOR   Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who won re-election to a third term last year, says that he is considering running for Governor next year, and he puts the odds that he will make the race as "at least 50-50 or better." B3. NEW YORK CITY  CHARGES FOR CREW OF IMMIGRANT SHIP   The captain and 10 crew members of the freighter that ran aground off Queens are charged with smuggling illegal aliens.  And the Immigration and Naturalization Service says that the 276 Chinese immigrants who were seized after they came ashore will remain in custody while their claims for political asylum are considered. A1.

nytimes_articles.headline: C.I.A. Funny Businesses
nytimes_articles.abstract: Erwin Rautenberg ran an air freight company in Los Angeles called Air-Sea Forwarders. But in 1956 he agreed to let the Central Intelligence Agency use the company name. In return he began handling some of the agency's air shipments. Air-Sea became a subsidiary of a C.I.A. proprietary called Air Asia. Now, Mr. Rautenberg says, the C.I.A. has left him holding the bag for huge debts.    That's the least of the troubles caused by proprietaries. These are corporations secretly owned by an intelligence agency that do business as private companies, or appear to. They provide useful cover for agents and launder money for covert operations. They also provide contacts with bona fide businesses to gather intelligence and facilitate covert operations. But they are open to abuse and are very difficult to police.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Forest Absorbs More Carbon Dioxide Than Was Predicted
nytimes_articles.abstract: FOR years, scientists concerned about the environmental effects of burning fossil fuels have tried to balance the global carbon budget. Now Harvard University researchers have found that temperate-zone forests may play a more important role in absorbing atmospheric carbon dioxide, a key greenhouse gas given off by burning, than was previously believed.   Greenhouse gases in the atmosphere are believed to trap heat, possibly leading to global warming.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Forced Smiles and Low Profiles in Romanian Tales
nytimes_articles.abstract: Compulsory Happiness  By Norman Manea Translated by Linda Coverdale. 259 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.   There's little laughter or forgiving in "Compulsory Happiness," Norman Manea's bold new book of stories, which confirms in fiction what was known in fact: during the reign of Nicolae Ceausescu, Romania was the most repressive of the Iron Curtain countries for writers with something to declare.

nytimes_articles.headline: Long Island Church At Center of Not What but Who
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was not what would be on the screen but who would be running the projector that sent a Long Island case to the United States Supreme Court.   And today the small church group that wanted to present movies in the high school auditorium after school hours said it would try again this fall to show films that it says promote Christian family values.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Season, Is Over, But Oakley Battles On
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Oakley wants more playing time next season. He would also like a contract extension. And if the Knicks do not meet his wishes, then Oakley will consider asking for a trade.   "I'm going to talk to David Checketts," Oakley said, referring to the Knicks' president. "I'm just not happy now. It's bad, because I don't get unhappy too much. I'm just not happy about a lot of things. I gave all I had. There's a lot that went on that people don't know about. I can't go through it another year."

nytimes_articles.headline: Q&A
nytimes_articles.abstract: Flitting Butterflies   Q.  Why do butterflies flit aimlessly, in a random path from point to point?   A. "It looks like flitting, but you're not the butterfly," said Dr. Louis Sorkin, an entomologist at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. Depending on the time of day and the species, he said, the butterfly could be searching for or avoiding a number of things.

nytimes_articles.headline: One for His Lifetime, Three for Her Crown
nytimes_articles.abstract: One two-time champion underwent a torturous four-hour test before being dethroned by a jubilant neophyte who spoiled his attempt to become the first American man to win three French Open titles. Another two-time champion was reinstated to the winner's circle, and to the world's No. 1 ranking, after a five-year drought in Paris that had left her shaken about her ability to perform like a champion at all.   The French Open remained the most grueling event on the Grand Slam calendar, an event that sometimes was metronomic because of its numerous baseline rallies. But this year its outcome was far from repetitious.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fixing Immigration
nytimes_articles.abstract: The human cargo washes up on America's shores -- Chinese bodies, Haitian bodies. Congress considers narrowing the gateway to liberty. Anti-immigration groups argue passionately that there is no more room at the American inn.   Will the United States always remain a refuge for the tired, the poor and the tempest-tossed? Or will the nation move, as Germany did last week, to restrict its policies of political asylum -- "to shut this traffic down," in the words of New York's top immigration official?

nytimes_articles.headline: Tokyo Journal; A Model Prince? Well, He Could Do the Washing
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Crown Prince Naruhito sips a cup of sacred sake at his wedding Wednesday morning, it will not only conclude his arduous courtship of his American-educated bride. It will also culminate the long and surprisingly public search for identity by Naruhito himself.   Most of the wedding publicity has focused on the future Empress, Masako Owada, a former Foreign Ministry official who was pursued by the Crown Prince for six years. Indeed, the publicity has overshadowed the man who is the most international, down-to-earth and perhaps the most ambiguous heir to the Chrysanthemum Throne in modern history.

nytimes_articles.headline: CAPTAIN AND CREW CHARGED IN VOYAGE OF CHINESE TO U.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: The captain and crew members of the decrepit freighter that ran aground off Queens were charged yesterday with smuggling illegal Chinese immigrants as Federal prosecutors described a bizarre voyage in which the agent of a crime boss in China seized control of the ship and locked the captain below deck.   The long, sweaty voyage began in January, according to a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday, as speedboats loaded the first of nearly 300 immigrants on the freighter in the South China Sea off Bangkok, later joined by more who boarded off Kenya. It ended when the captain and crew twice failed to make rendezvous with smaller ships in the Atlantic to carry the immigrants to America, leading to a mutiny.  A Desperate Struggle    An immigrant on board, hired by a crime boss to transport the human cargo, then took the freighter to New York, where the ship ran hard aground off the Rockaway Peninsula early Sunday as he tried to drop off the passengers, the Federal complaint said. With their goal in sight, the startled immigrants rushed to the deck and leaped into the sea, beginning a desperate, frantic struggle through the pounding surf, in which eight of them died.

nytimes_articles.headline: Iraqi Refugees : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "For the Enemies of the Saudis' Enemy, a 'Cemetery'" (Opinion, April 10) by Flora Lewis: .The true situation in the Saudi refugee camps has been verified by the United Nations and the International Red Cross, as well as prominent me

nytimes_articles.headline: Held Accountable : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "The Muzzle of 'Correctness' Has an Ugly History" (Meanwhile, May 13) by Richard Harwood: .Before political correctness was labeled as such, it was called common sense. You considered what you said before you said it. Are we now, in

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   BOSTON RED SOX -- Signed Craig Phillip, Shayne Bennett, Steve Hayward, Shawn Senior and Greg Kennedy, pitchers; Kevin Clark, Lou Merloni and Jim Murphy, infielders, and Fausto Abad, Wilfredo Rivera and Eric Ford, outfielders.   KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Signed Phillip Brassington, Nevin Brewer, Jason Huffman, and Matthew Aminoff, pitchers; Larry Smith, outfielder; Lino Diaz and Stephen Wojtkowski, third basemen, and Daron Dondero, shortstop.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ghost Town Where Byzantines Mined Gold
nytimes_articles.abstract: ARCHEOLOGISTS exploring a ghost town in the remote eastern desert of Egypt have discovered the remains of what almost certainly was a major gold-mining operation for the Byzantine Empire. The stark granite cliffs surrounding the town were the source of a rich supply of the metal that gilded the icons and lavish art of early Christianity.   The site, called Bir Umm Fawakhir, should give scholars a rare look at the conditions of ordinary people in Byzantine Egypt, a poorly understood period from A.D. 330, when control of the Roman Empire shifted to Constantinople, until the Muslim conquest in A.D. 642.

nytimes_articles.headline: ISRAELIS SOUNDING UPBEAT ON TALKS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Israeli leaders offered unusually optimistic assessments of the Middle East peace talks today, with Foreign Minister Shimon Peres saying that Israel and Jordan were so close to an agreement that "we just have to take out the pen and sign."   The upbeat mood echoed remarks several days ago by the new Jordanian Prime Minister, Abdul-Salam Majali, who forecast breakthroughs before the end of the year that could produce Israeli accords not just with Jordan but also with other Arab neighbors.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Defers Response to Iraqis' Plot Against Bush
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration will postpone a decision about whether to retaliate against Iraq for its apparent sponsorship of an assassination plot against former President George Bush until Kuwait completes its trial of the suspects in the case.   In a first day of testimony last weekend, two Iraqis pleaded guilty to carrying out the plot at the behest of Iraqi intelligence agents. But Administration officials said today that the nature of an American response would depend on whether the Kuwaiti proceedings are regarded as fair.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; A Tribute to a Ballet Master, in Workshop Form
nytimes_articles.abstract: George Balanchine was doubly honored last weekend. The New York City Ballet continued its Balanchine Celebration at the New York State Theater. Nearby, at the Juilliard Theater, the company's School of American Ballet offered its own mini-celebration.    The school's 29th annual Workshop Performances were devoted entirely to choreography by Balanchine. The standard of dancing was very high on Saturday afternoon and evening. Both programs included the same ballets, but there were changes of cast in several roles. One complete work was given, as well as excerpts from five others.

nytimes_articles.headline: Military Justice
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Airman Apprentice Terry M. Helvey got what he deserved for killing Radioman Allen R. Schindler: life imprisonment (front page, May 28). But why was Mr. Schindler, who had a fine Navy record, being discharged merely for identifying himself as a homosexual and Mr. Helvey, with a "long history of violence and bullying," not considered for discharge? Instead of arguing that homosexuals should not serve in the military because they may be harmed, why don't we get rid of those people who would use violence -- a real threat to military discipline -- against their fellows?  ARLENE EISENBERG  New York, May 28, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: Cost Cutters Shouldn't Target Elderly Widows
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your longstanding commitment to defending the rights of those without access to political power deserves the commendation of all of society. In editorials and columns, your newspaper has championed women, minorities, the less affluent and the disadvantaged. However, a group that is overwhelmingly composed of older women, many of them members of minority ethnic elements, is being subjected to unfair treatment by the Federal Government. I refer to the future survivors, almost all widows, of retired Federal employees.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton was on the Washington end of a speaker phone Sunday evening as 50 friends of VIRGINIA KELLEY sang "Happy Birthday" at her 70th-birthday celebration in the Las Vegas home of Dr. Elias Ghanem. Dr. Ghanem raised funds for the Clinton campaign last year. Among the guests were Wayne Newton and Col. Tom Parker, formerly Elvis Presley's manager, The Associated Press reported.   Wishing his mother well, the President said that she seemed to be having a good time in Las Vegas. Mrs. Kelley spent last week at the Mirage Hotel there with her husband, Richard Kelley. She is planning to be in Washington this week for eighth-grade graduation of her granddaughter, Chelsea.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Reisinger knockout team championship ended on Sunday in a victory for John Roberts, George Tornay, Saul Bronstein and August Boehm, all of Manhattan, and Bob Sartorius of Lake Hiawatha, N.J.    In the final at the Manhattan Club, at 23 West 72d Street, they trailed throughout but surged in the last quarter to win by 20 imps against Peter Parella, Bjorn Fallenius, Jacqui Mitchell and Judge Amalya Kearse, all of Manhattan; Bob Jones of Auburndale, Queens, and Dr. Howard Hertzberg of Alpine, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Inquiry on General's Remarks
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Air Force said tonight that it was investigating reports that a two-star general had disparaged President Clinton in a speech, calling him, among other things, a "pot-smoking" and "draft-dodging" Commander in Chief.   The investigation, disclosed tonight by The Washington Post, was confirmed by an Air Force spokesman who identifying the officer as Maj. Gen. Harold N. Campbell.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton in the Trenches : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Clinton Is Booed at Vietnam Memorial" (June 1): .Why do headlines so frequently accentuate the negative? Even when President Bill Clinton does something that is clearly seen by the majority as positive - and the article says that t

nytimes_articles.headline: Answer: A Value-Added Tax
nytimes_articles.abstract: Equity or efficiency arguments can be made for each of President Clinton's tax proposals. But there are also legitimate problems with each of them.    Opening up a large gap between the maximum personal income tax rate (a proposed 40 percent) and capital gains tax rate (28 percent) creates an enormous incentive to get back into the loophole business.

nytimes_articles.headline: Under-30 Crowd Piles Up Under-70 Scores
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the Saint Andrews Golf Club was established in Yonkers in 1888, the New York area became the cradle of the game in America. In the next two weeks, it will be the nerve center.   Beginning Thursday, the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y., will once again be the site of the Buick Classic. And next week, the Baltusrol Country Club in Springfield, N.J., will host the United States Open for a record seventh time.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article in Your Money on May 8 about personal bankruptcy misstated the court fee for filing a petition under Chapter 13 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. It is $150. This correction was delayed because the author of the article did not learn of the error, from a telephone caller, until her return from vacation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Employers Taken For Philanthropists
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A May 20 news analysis on health care states of President Clinton: "He has already said he wants employers to pay for the cost. He is considering two forms of taxation, requiring employers to pay either a fixed percentage of the total payroll or a fixed amount of money for each worker."

nytimes_articles.headline: Leeway on Searches
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Justices ruled that the police do not need a warrant to seize drugs detected while frisking a suspect for concealed weapons. Page A23.

nytimes_articles.headline: Voters Choose Florio Opponent Today
nytimes_articles.abstract: New Jersey's long and expensive campaign for the Republican nomination for governor concludes on Tuesday, when as few as 120,000 voters can select the candidate who will oppose Jim Florio in November.   Secretary of State Daniel Dalton predicted that only 16 to 19 percent of the state's 4 million registered voters would cast ballots in both the Republican and Democratic primaries. Based on past performance, that means only 350,000 or so voters are likely to turn out in the Republican primary, dividing their votes among the party's three major candidates.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bulls' Ethic in the Finals: Work Those Suns Weary
nytimes_articles.abstract: He understands how they think. He knows how to make them uncomfortable. Now that B. J. Armstrong's role with the Chicago Bulls has expanded to include a starting spot and specific defensive assignments, he can draw upon his previous basketball life as an outstanding offensive player at the high school and college level.   Armstrong's 3-point shooting percentage of .453 led the National Basketball Association this season. But it is his role within Chicago's defensive structure, and his ability to share in the attempted containment of Phoenix guard Kevin Johnson, that could become a central factor in the championship series against the Suns, which begins Wednesday night in Phoenix.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Singapore Girl
nytimes_articles.abstract: .When the life-size figure of a Singapore Airlines flight attendant is installed this month at Madame Tussaud's waxworks in London alongside such other recently arrived celebrities as Presidents Bill Clinton and Saddam Hussein, it will mark a signific

nytimes_articles.headline: No Agreement on Budget As Talks Pass Deadline
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mayor David N. Dinkins abruptly broke off negotiations with the City Council on a $31 billion budget early this morning without reaching an agreement on how to fill a $300 million budget gap.   The Mayor, dressed in sweatpants and a windbreaker, marched silently and quickly through a legion of lobbyists and out of City Hall at 1:20 A.M., after a full day of talks failed to produce a compromise. Although his departure was considered a setback, negotiations were expected to resume sometime today.

nytimes_articles.headline: Santos Is Suspended
nytimes_articles.abstract: Belmont Park stewards suspended jockey JOSE SANTOS for seven days, from June 11 through June 17, for careless riding. Santos was cited yesterday for his ride aboard Runaway Storm in Belmont's second race on June 6. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: N.Y.R.A.-OTB Merger?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The 23 trustees of the New York Racing Association will receive a private briefing tomorrow by members of the Governor's Advisory Commission on Racing in the 21st Century and will reportedly be told that N.Y.R.A. must be receptive to negotiating a merger with the Off-Track Betting Corporation.   "From our perspective," an executive of the commission said yesterday, "this is N.Y.R.A.'s best and last hope to work cooperatively with the state. Both N.Y.R.A. and OTB are in big trouble financially, and they will have to be willing to follow the commission's report and try to negotiate a longterm relationship with the Offtrack Betting Corporation."

nytimes_articles.headline: Power in a Small Box
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Hewlett-Packard Company introduced a new subnotebook computer yesterday, the 2.9-pound Omni Book 300. It appears to be the best compromise yet for those people who demand full power to run Windows software in the smallest and lightest possible package.   The Omni Book 300 packs a lot of technology into its trim, black case, which measures 11 inches wide by 6.4 inches deep by 1.4 inches tall. Those dimensions make it substantially smaller than a conventional notebook computer, but still wide enough for a full-size keyboard and deep enough for a generous monochrome VGA display.

nytimes_articles.headline: Political Memo; A Landslide Remakes Texas's Political Landscape
nytimes_articles.abstract: For Texas Democrats, and for Gov. Ann W. Richards in particular, it is not a good sign when party insiders here start making nervous cracks about Yellow Dog Republicans.   There has never been any such thing as a Yellow Dog Republican in Texas, of course. From the Civil War on, the term applied to loyal Democrats, so named, the legend goes, because they would vote for a yellow dog before they would vote for any Republican.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton in the Trenches : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The media continue to inform us that President Bill Clinton lacks military experience and therefore cannot come to a decision regarding U.S. action in Bosnia. But if we look at recent U.S. presidents, we see that Harry Truman served as a low-ranking offi

nytimes_articles.headline: Political Memo; Answer: Cut Entitlements. Question: But How?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Like a weed run rampant, entitlement programs are taking over the Federal budget, and unless they are brought under control, politicians and economists agree, no hope exists for lowering the deficit in the long run.   The issue dominated the House debate on President Clinton's budget last month and is sure to be a main element of the debate in the Senate later this month.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge Allows Dredging To Continue
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Federal judge held today that a permit for ocean disposal of dioxin-tainted silt from Newark Bay was flawed, but he rejected pleas from environmentalists that the dredging and dumping be halted.   The judge, Dickinson R. Debevoise of United States District Court here, said that the Army Corps of Engineers, which granted the permit to port officials, had failed to show that the dioxin existed only in trace amounts, less than 1 part per trillion. Federal law permits ocean disposal of dioxin only in trace amounts.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: COLLEGE BASEBALL  Sun Devils Are Sent Packing  Jay Hogue shut down top-ranked Arizona State with four innings of two-hit relief and Ernesto Rivera singled to break a 4-4 tie with two down in the eighth inning as Oklahoma State stayed alive in the College World Series with a 5-4 victory yesterday. The Cowboys (44-16) advanced to an elimination game today against the loser of last night's game between Texas and Wichita State. Arizona State (46-20) was eliminated. It was only the second time in 16 trips to Omaha that the Sun Devils failed to win a game. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Worker-Participation Programs Are Found Illegal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Employers, lawyers and business trade associations expressed dismay yesterday after the National Labor Relations Board ruled that an employee-involvement program at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company violated Federal labor laws.   The board ordered Du Pont last week to dismantle seven committees established to deal with safety and recreation issues at the Chambers Works plant in Deepwater, N.J., and to bargain in good faith with the plant's union, the Chemical Workers Association.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chess
nytimes_articles.abstract: If you are going to play a match billed as the world championship -- even though it is apparently not going to be sanctioned by the International Chess Federation -- it is important for your morale not to falter in the last competition before you turn from practice to the vital pre-match study. That is surely why Nigel Short, Gary Kasparov's challenger in their renegade title contest in London coming up in September, put on a special final-round effort to tie for first in the Verenigde Spaarbank International Tournament in Amsterdam in early May. Short had announced that he would make this his last tourney before meeting Kasparov.   At the start of Round 6 of the six-round event, which was held as a memorial to Max Euwe, the former world champion from the Netherlands, Short trailed the leader, Viswanathan Anand of India, by a point. He defeated Anand impressively, however, and like his co-winners, Anand and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, was awarded a prize of about $6,500.

nytimes_articles.headline: Morrison Defeats Foreman By Decision
nytimes_articles.abstract: George Foreman sucked in his stomach tonight and stayed upright once again. Tommy Morrison flailed at the 44-year-old aspiring actor, and hit him high and in the tummy, but it was as if Morrison were asking Foreman to leave a kitchen.   Foreman would not budge.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: New Trade Plan for Tokyo   The White House offered a plan for specific import targets to reduce Japan's trade surplus. Page D1. Discrimination Suit Settled    New York City will promote about 75 white supervisors at the Human Resources Administration who said they were discriminated against. Page B1. Setback for Space Station    A design team said all options for a scaled-down version of the space station exceeded budget goals. Page C8.

nytimes_articles.headline: Search Advances For 'Antisense' Drugs
nytimes_articles.abstract: SCIENTISTS at a small biotechnology company have taken a significant step toward developing a new class of drugs designed to block the action of specific genes. Such drugs hold the potential to treat many viruses and cancers that elude current therapies.   The drugs are an improved version of "antisense" agents, chemicals intended to target and impede messenger RNA, which mediates translation of the genetic information of DNA into specific proteins. The researchers, from Gilead Sciences Inc. of Foster City, Calif., report their findings in the current issue of Science.

nytimes_articles.headline: Assembly Approves Ban on Assault Weapons
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York State Assembly approved a near-total ban on assault weapons today, the first time that either house of the Legislature has acted to outlaw possession of the rapid-firing guns.   Officials in the Republican-controlled Senate, where an assault-weapon has never been voted out of committee, said passage of the bill is doubtful. But the bill's Senate sponsor said he was hopeful that the vote by the Democratic-majority Assembly would improve the bill's chances.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Mind; Give Them a Parade
nytimes_articles.abstract: Let them in, those heroes from China, those men and women who sought the beautiful land, let them out of detention as swiftly as possible and then treat them with the courtesy, dignity and respect their brave hearts merit -- that is what America should do for its own soul's sake.   Worry later about the fears of our poor little country being swamped by hordes of refugees. But right now, how I hope that the Mayor of New York City will walk down Broadway to City Hall with them, and tell them to come and see him personally if anybody tries to squeeze blackmail money out of their foul months at sea.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article yesterday about the observance of the 25th anniversary of Robert F. Kennedy's assassination referred incorrectly to an associate of the Senator's who attended. He is John Seigenthaler, a retired newspaper editor and former Kennedy spokesman.

nytimes_articles.headline: Good Ethics, Good Health Economics
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Americans have embraced our individual right to limit heroic but futile medical treatment at the end of life with such documents as an advance directive, living will and health care proxy. How can we combine this ethical consensus with the economics of rationing care? 

The coming reform of our health care system may provide an opportunity. First, current law should be amended to require all registrants for Federal entitlement programs -- Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security benefits -- to consider and complete an advance directive.

nytimes_articles.headline: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Benjamin S. Carson; For Many, Pediatric Neurosurgeon Is a Folk Hero
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN he first came to Johns Hopkins Hospital as a neurosurgery resident, Dr. Benjamin S. Carson was occasionally mistaken for an orderly. "It wasn't deliberately racist," he recalled, without a trace of bitterness. "It's just that orderlies were the only black hospital employees these people had ever seen before."   Today, at age 41, eight years after becoming the nation's youngest chief of pediatric neurosurgery -- he is one of only three African-Americans in that position -- Dr. Carson is arguably the most famous surgeon on the Hopkins staff. As director of the 22-member team that in 1987 successfully separated Siamese twins joined at the head, he was in the national news for weeks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Immigrant Dream of Plenty Turns to Misery and Regret
nytimes_articles.abstract: It took $27,000 of borrowed money, a harrowing 52-day voyage by sea eating rotten rice and two days by van and on foot from Mexico before Hua Zhen was finally smuggled into the United States from China. That was six weeks ago, before another ship bulging with passengers like him ran aground off of New York City, when Mr. Hua was still flush with hope.    Already, gloom has consumed Mr. Hua, who would give only the nickname his friends call him. He is homesick, deeply in debt, and still in pursuit of work while he lives with relatives in New Jersey. At best, he hopes to land a job as a dishwasher in a New York restaurant and maybe a bunk to call his own above the kitchen. Not until years in the future, once his passage is repaid, does he imagine he will see his wife and 10-year-old son again.  'A Modern-Day Slave Trade'    "I regret coming," he said. "I feel like I was tricked. Everybody said life in America is wonderful, that everyone has a big car and a big house."

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Watch Over Me' to Close
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me," a drama by Frank McGuinness, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. The matinee of the play, directed by Robert Lefevre, will be its 232d regular performance; it had five previews.

nytimes_articles.headline: . . . And Historic Scorer
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANTHONY YEBOAH became the first black player and only the second foreigner to win the German scoring title because of four goals that didn't count for his team.   The 27-year-old Yeboah, a Ghanan who plays for Eintracht Frankfurt, ended the season Saturday with 20 goals, tied with ULF KIRSTEN of Bayer Leverkusen for the Bundesliga lead.

nytimes_articles.headline: Observer; Elvis, Pelvis & Mundt
nytimes_articles.abstract: David Halberstam's new book about the 1950's -- titled "The Fifties," believe it or not -- makes them feel heavier with significance than they felt to me while they were still in progress. This shows once again how hard it is to see the forest when you spend ten years up to your eyeballs in trees.   From his commanding vantage high upon a peak in the faraway 1990's, Halberstam can see, for instance, that Elvis Presley was one of the most important phenomena of the 1950's, in a class with the invention of the hydrogen bomb.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Peek Behind the Smile At Rough Journey's End
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE photograph on the front page of The Times on Monday showing a huddled mass of Chinese certainly evoked hard passages and disorientation. It showed the illegal refugees looking out in grayness at the grounded steamer that had carried them 17,000 miles to Jacob Riis beach. But there in the left-hand corner was a laughing face. Wet and cold, a man was plainly laughing.   For months he traveled on a tramp steamer where close to 300 people ultimately gave up sharing a single toilet. He has arrived in America with nothing more than his clothes and they were soaking wet. He may not have realized it when the picture was taken, but at least six of his fellow passengers died in the last leg of the voyage through the waters of Queens.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Card Deal for Major League Alumni
nytimes_articles.abstract: BROOKS ROBINSON may not stand to make as much from Nabisco as the $126,000 the Baltimore Orioles paid him back in 1976, but who knows? If enough people send in a couple of Nabisco boxtops and a $5 bill for his autographed new baseball card, the company might be tempted to renew its limited new promotion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Whatever way one cuts it, whether by a Vance-Owen fig leaf or bold annexation, Greater Serbia has won the day. Will our governments now allow the regime to plunder Macedonia, Vojvodina and Kosovo?

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Theater: Playland; South Africa's Conflict, Boiled Down to 2 Men
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The whole world is me and you. Here! Now!," says the white man to the black man in "Playland," the new drama written and directed by Athol Fugard. "Forgive me or kill me. That's the only choice you've got."   With those few sentences, Mr. Fugard not only delivers the crux of his play at the Manhattan Theater Club Stage II but also sums up the crisis in South Africa now that apartheid is finally crumbling. In "Playland," as in so much of his canon, this great writer boils down his country's tragedy to the simplest theatrical essentials: a couple of actors, a barren setting, a single confrontation, one act. It's a welcome return to solid artistic ground for Mr. Fugard after the groping of such recent efforts as "My Children! My Africa!" and "A Place With the Pigs."

nytimes_articles.headline: Nominee Rejection Costs Club An Event
nytimes_articles.abstract: An all-white yacht club's refusal to admit a black dentist for membership has caused national sailing officials to withdraw a major youth championship regatta scheduled to begin June 18 at the Florida Yacht Club in Jacksonville, Fla.    The membership rejection, which has drawn criticism from the United States Navy as well as Jacksonville city officials, has put the spotlight on a sport still known for its long-standing image of elitism.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; 1-800-UH OH
nytimes_articles.abstract: I am not what you would call a compulsive shopper. I am more of a manic-depressive shopper; first I buy things, then I feel bad about it.    My problem has been exacerbated by the meteoric rise of catalogue shopping in America over the last 10 years. During the next 20 minutes, it is not totally beyond the realm of possibility that I could acquire a pair of gardening clogs, a rustic birdhouse, a dog bed filled with cedar shavings or a pair of silk charmeuse lounging pajamas merely by picking up the phone. A confab with the 800 operator for the J. Crew company is much better than hot milk for combating insomnia. The U.P.S. truck pulls up to the house like a loyal dog, big and brown.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Balanchine's Wide Range, Classicism To Jazz
nytimes_articles.abstract: Take a company like the New York City Ballet, in which standards are already higher than the norm, and superlatives immediately come to mind. Yet even by those standards, the City Ballet's dancers seem suddenly to have recharged themselves.   "La Source," George Balanchine's strange if exquisite meditation on the French style in ballet, was restored to its essence on Saturday afternoon by Nikolaj Hubbe, Kyra Nichols and Katrina Killian. It was a performance imbued with greatness, matched later by that of Darci Kistler and Robert La Fosse, surpassing even their usual excellence, in the Gerswhin "Who Cares?" Judith Fugate and Lourdes Lopez were no slouches, either, and the four principals plunged deliciously into the jazzy "Clap Yo' Hands" section, danced to a recorded piano solo by George Gershwin that Balanchine dropped from the ballet shortly after its 1970 premiere.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Leadership Can Still Make a Crucial Difference
nytimes_articles.abstract: The international community is being given a third opportunity to steer the conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina to a close. But it is again likely to miss its chance. Each effort is considerably more onerous than the last, and the cost is increasing sharply.

nytimes_articles.headline: Serbs Are Right to Laugh at the West's Posturing
nytimes_articles.abstract: Incoherency and cruelty have tragically characterized the intervention of the European and world communities in the Balkan drama. As a former foreign minister of France, I was recently asked to describe the international decision-making process in the pa

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Words Lightly and Seriously but Always Lovingly
nytimes_articles.abstract: Misreadings  By Umberto Eco  Translated by William Weaver. 180 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace. $12.95 (paper).  Words to Create a World  Interviews, Essays and Reviews of Contemporary Poetry  By Daniel Hoffman  301 pages. University of Michigan Press.    One of Somerset Maugham's admiring readers once asked him how he was able to create such artful short stories and novels. "It's not difficult," he replied. "You can find all the words I use in one book: the dictionary. I simply rearrange them." In "The Summing Up," he made a somewhat more serious observation about the printed word: "I would sooner read a timetable or a catalogue than nothing at all. They are much more entertaining than half the novels that are written."

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Adventures in Spoletoland: Conservative but Not Bloodless
nytimes_articles.abstract: Spoleto Festival U.S.A., held annually here, is troubled by difficult questions in its 17th year. Has this multi-disciplinary event lost its edge, its experimental thrust? Will it overcome internal squabbles and financial crises? Could it survive without the guidance of its 82-year-old founder, Gian Carlo Menotti?   A single weekend's visit did not provide ready answers. For the moment, the festival seems to be on reasonably firm musical ground; there were solid productions of two unjustly neglected operas, some attractive programs of chamber music and a brand-new children's opera by Mr. Menotti. Crowds were large, concessions brisk, publicity relentless.

nytimes_articles.headline: Book Notes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dead and Alive   "Embraced by the Light," Betty J. Eadie's account of how she died after a hysterectomy, rose to heaven to meet Jesus and scores of angels and then returned with a jolt to her body, initially seemed a bit far out to many members of Manhattan's decidedly cynical publishing world. But 590,000 copies have already been printed, and the book is nearing its fifth week on the New York Times best-seller list, where it moves into the No. 6 spot on Sunday.    Not bad for a first-time author and grief counselor who received no advance and for a publisher that has printed only one book, this one. "Everyone told us that a near-death book wouldn't sell," said the book's publisher, Marc Stephen Garrison, an entrepreneur and author of business books from Sundance, Utah. Mr. Garrison, who owns a tuna-fishing fleet and a travel agency, among other things, founded Gold Leaf Press specifically for Mrs. Eadie's book.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article in Business Day on May 31, about the Securities and Exchange Commission's new proxy rules, misstated the percentage of the shares in Consolidated Freightways Inc. that are owned by members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The company's employee stock ownership plan, which includes other employees as well as members of the teamsters' union, owns 13 percent.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Golden Venture, Plus 100,000
nytimes_articles.abstract: The four-month nightmare voyage of the Golden Venture ended Sunday morning when the tramp freighter dumped its starving and frightened cargo of nearly 300 Chinese immigrants into frigid waters off one of New York City's most popular public beaches. Six passengers died from drowning or exposure, several had to be hospitalized and the remainder were sent to detention centers to await Federal hearings.    But for the estimated 100,000 illegal Chinese immigrants who arrive each year, mostly to New York, the nightmare typically goes on and on. The $3,000 down payment they make to "snakehead" smugglers before departure -- several years' earnings for a typical Chinese -- covers barely a tenth of what they must ultimately pay to travel huddled below deck for months without adequate food or sanitation. The remaining money must be paid off through years of indentured servitude -- virtual slavery -- in Chinese restaurants and sweatshops.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Serbs Suffer, Too : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: As every responsible leader and Balkan expert knows, forcible UN intervention against the Serbs in Bosnia would mean an international war. .Self-defense is what the Bosnian Serbs are engaged in - they own more than 60 percent of the land in Bosnia. The

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: We do not want American soldiers to die for us. No American troops, please. We are capable and willing to fight and die for our country ourselves. All we would like to see is the lifting of the weapons embargo.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins-Council Talks Halt, Then Resume
nytimes_articles.abstract: Talks between Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council over the city's $31.4 billion budget resumed yesterday afternoon, but the two sides remained apart on at least three crucial issues.   Council leaders and the Mayor continued to disagree over whether to create a new agency for the homeless, whether the Council should have a say in a new quasi-public corporation to build health clinics, and how to cut $300 million more from the spending plan to make up for a shortfall in state and Federal aid.

nytimes_articles.headline: Details Emerge, but Petrovic's Death Still Baffles
nytimes_articles.abstract: The death of Drazen Petrovic, a Croatian player who with the Nets became one of the National Basketball Association's top shooting guards, sent shock waves yesterday throughout this country and much of Europe, where his career began.   Petrovic was killed instantly Monday when the car in which he was riding slammed into a trailer truck on a rain-slick road in Germany. He was 28.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is simply not a morally sustainable stance by the West to assert that it is wrong to provide even defensive weaponry to the victims of naked Serbian aggression on the ground that this would prolong the fighting. .If this is so, how can we ethically

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Thursday about Asian-Americans' political campaigns referred incorrectly to their record in mayoralties of major cities. The first such winner was Norman Y. Mineta, a Japanese-American, who served as Mayor of San Jose, Calif., from 1971 until 1974, when he was elected to Congress.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "These are life-and-death issues. We just cannot wait until health-care reform is adopted and we have a health insurance system for the whole country." -- ROSALIE GAULL SILBERMAN of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, on access to health insurance.  [ A1:5. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: True to Style, Mayor Tells Boston He Will Get His Way as Envoy to Vatican
nytimes_articles.abstract: People here have been telling Ray Flynn stories since the popular, populist Mayor announced at a tearful news conference outside his Gate of Heaven church in March that he would leave by early July to become Ambassador to the Vatican.    But now the latest one, already being proclaimed a Ray Flynn classic, is unfolding: the former Providence College basketball star goes one on one with the State Department over his job description, and wins.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Knick Fine for Oakley?
nytimes_articles.abstract: After complaining publicly about his playing time, his contract and his role, power forward Charles Oakley met yesterday with Dave Checketts, the Knicks' president. While Checketts would not say if any disciplinary action would be taken against Oakley for speaking out before speaking with him, a fine is probably forthcoming for the Knicks' co-captain.   "This is the second time Charles has done something like this," said Checketts, referring to an incident last season when Oakley said the Knicks made a mistake by failing to keep Xavier McDaniel. "It's almost like Charles is a volcano waiting to erupt. It's O.K. to be frustrated after a season, but this is not the way to handle it. Discussions like that should be kept inside. I'm disappointed, but we'll deal with it."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Serbs Suffer, Too : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: One solution is to arm the Croats and Bosnians, and intervene actively against the Serbs with NATO air power. .The other, certainly safer and more humane in the short term, would be to acknowledge openly the inevitability of Greater Serbia (with all du

nytimes_articles.headline: Vichy Aide Accused of War Crimes Is Slain in France
nytimes_articles.abstract: A prominent official in France's collaborationist Vichy government who was facing charges of crimes against humanity for deporting Jews to Nazi death camps during World War II was shot dead by a lone gunman at his home here early today.   A few hours later, a 49-year-old frustrated author, Christian Didier, was charged with murder in the death of Rene Bousquet, 84. Before his arrest, Mr. Didier summoned television reporters to a suburban hotel and recounted in detail how he had fired four bullets at the man he described as "that piece of garbage."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Pop Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: Beck on Track   Jeff Beck, one of rock's most influential guitarists, is traveling along new byways and retracing old ones.   Later this month, Epic will release "Crazy Legs," an album that brings Mr. Beck together with a British roots-rock band, the Big Town Playboys, in a collection of classics originally performed by the 1950's rocker Gene Vincent and his band the Blue Caps. The album, a tribute to the Blue Caps' original lead guitarist, Cliff Gallup, features Mr. Beck playing what he says he was struggling to learn to play when he was 15 years old.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Bad Malpractice Idea
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The Clinton Administration's proposal to shift the malpractice burden from physicians to insurance companies (front page, May 21) is 180 degrees off course. At first glance, from the physician's point of view, it seems a good idea; however, in the long run it would not reduce the cost of health care, but probably increase it.   It has been shown time after time that a trusting and close relationship between physician and patient prevents a lawsuit if a complication or problem arises. When complaints are addressed to a faceless, large corporation with deep pockets, there will be no personal ties to prevent or moderate lawsuits. Also, corporations do not settle claims quickly; but seem always to be involved in drawn-out and costly proceedings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Simmons in Hospital With Chest Pains
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Pirates' general manager, TED SIMMONS, was admitted to St. Francis General Hospital in Pittsburgh yesterday with chest pains and was in stable condition. Simmons, 43, had a series of tests after being admitted, according to a short statement issued by the Pirates. He is expected to remain hospitalized for the next several days.   A Pirates spokesman, JIM TRDINICH, said that after developing the pain, Simmons consulted with Trainer KENT BIGGERSTAFF before being admitted to the hospital.

nytimes_articles.headline: Behind Dinkins Budget: Recovering From Gamble
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the end, the election-year budget that Mayor David N. Dinkins hoped would demonstrate his managerial mettle came a year too soon.   The staffs of the Mayor and the City Council were still working last night, five days into their final round of negotiations, trying to resolve the last details of the city's spending plan for the fiscal year starting next month. But the budget's thrust is clear: it will feature about $300 million in spending cuts and a retrenchment in some services not likely to endear Mr. Dinkins and other political leaders with voters this fall.

nytimes_articles.headline: L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L, L!
nytimes_articles.abstract: A start might bring an end. That was the theory, anyway, concerning Anthony Young and his 19 straight defeats.   "Put his destiny in his hands," Manager Dallas Green had said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Does anyone seriously believe that the European powers would not intervene in ex-Yugoslavia if Bosnian Muslims were implicated in the "ethnic cleansing" of Croatian Catholics? Does anyone seriously believe that America would not intervene in Bo

nytimes_articles.headline: The Serbs Suffer, Too : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Even if it were true that the media in Belgrade are controlled (and they are not), how do you explain the fact that hundreds of thousands of Serbs living abroad are, if anything, even more determined to support the struggle for the independence of Serbs

nytimes_articles.headline: BOYCOTT OF ISRAEL IS SAID TO RELAX
nytimes_articles.abstract: Most Arab countries have dropped the decades-long boycott of companies that do business with Israel, a senior Kuwaiti official said today, but direct commercial dealings with Israel will have to await the conclusion of peace treaties.   The assertion by Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad, Kuwait's First Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, confirms an evident trend that has been taking place quietly in the past few years as one Arab country after another has abandoned the commercial boycott on foreign companies that do business with Israel.

nytimes_articles.headline: Senate Panel Backs Military Spending the Pentagon Never Sought
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Senate committee followed the House today in approving $1.2 billion in military spending that the Pentagon had not asked for.   With no extended argument or questioning, the Appropriations Committee sent to the Senate floor a measure that also includes $400 million of the $19.3 billion in economic-stimulus spending President Clinton asked for last winter.

nytimes_articles.headline: Princeton President Addresses Graduates
nytimes_articles.abstract: Princeton University conferred 1,075 undergraduate and 611 advanced degrees yesterday at its 246th commencement held on the lawn in front of Nassau Hall in Princeton, N.J.   The valedictory was delivered by Niles A. Pierce, a mechanical and aerospace engineering major. D. Graham Burnett, a history major, was the salutatorian, delivering his speech in Latin as Princeton tradition requires.

nytimes_articles.headline: Like It or Not, We Must Lead
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff caused an uproar recently when he said the United States was withdrawing from its role as international leader.

The chief problem with American foreign policy, however, is not what he said but what the Clinton Administration has not said.

Unlike cold war Administrations, whose central international goal -- the containment of the Soviet Union -- was fixed, the Clinton Administration must devise and present its own vision of American purposes in the world. It has not done so.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kentucky Extends Pitino's Contract
nytimes_articles.abstract: RICK PITINO's contract extension calls for him to remain as head basketball coach at the University of Kentucky into the next century. The school announced yesterday that Pitino's contract was extended through the 1999-2000 season.   "I think he made a career decision, that he wants to be a college coach, and he wants to be a college coach at Kentucky," the Kentucky athletic director, C.M. NEWTON said after a meeting of the Kentucky Athletics Association's board of directors in Lexington.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: There are two major single knockout team championships in New York City, the Grand National and the Reisinger, and one player has a remarkable streak in progress. A year ago, George Tornay of Manhattan won the Grand National Swiss teams plus the subsequent knockout and was a runner-up in the Reisinger. This year he again won the Grand National Swiss, was a winner Sunday in the Reisinger, and later this month will compete in the final of the Grand National knockout. John Roberts and August Boehm also won five of the six events but were derailed in the sixth by external circumstances and had to withdraw. Stay tuned for next year to see if the streak will continue.   On the diagramed deal from the Reisinger semifinal Tornay held the South cards. He had a difficult rebid after opening one diamond and hearing a one-spade response, and made a slightly eccentric rebid. He chose three no-trump, which is normally based on stoppers in the unbid suits, which he had, and a long solid suit, which he did not have.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mourning Hero Who Transcended Sports World
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fans gathered in front of the coffee bar co-owned by the New Jersey Nets star Drazen Petrovic to pay tribute today to the basketball player and national hero of this war-torn country who died in a car accident Monday in Germany.   A mound of freshly lighted candles outside Cafe Amadeus illuminated scores of crying faces as people sat in silence in front of pictures of Petrovic, whom many regarded proudly as a symbol of this newly-independent republic's nationhood.

nytimes_articles.headline: Graf and Agassi Uncertain for Wimbledon
nytimes_articles.abstract: With Wimbledon set to start in less than two weeks, STEFFI GRAF and ANDRE AGASSI are nursing injuries that might keep them from defending their titles.   Graf, who won the French Open on Saturday, was then treated at a hospital in Essen, Germany, for an injury suffered during her quarterfinal match, last Wednesday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Angelenos Vote A Conservative As New Mayor
nytimes_articles.abstract: Richard Riordan, a conservative businessman, was elected Mayor of Los Angeles tonight, ushering in a new political era after the 20-year leadership of Tom Bradley and his coalition of blacks and white liberals.   Mr. Riordan, 62, defeated Michael Woo, a liberal City Councilman, in a hard-fought, nonpartisan race in which personal attacks drowned out serious debate over the future of this city as it struggles with its evolving multi-ethnic identity and with the aftermath of last year's riots.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge Orders The Release Of Haitians
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Federal judge ordered yesterday that all Haitians held in a detention camp at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base be released and that the camp -- opened two years ago in an effort to stem a flood of Haitian immigrants -- be closed immediately.   Unless the Clinton Administration files an appeal, the ruling by Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. in the United States District Court in Brooklyn will close a painful chapter in America's immigration history.

nytimes_articles.headline: Our Failure to Help Bosnia Will Mean Lasting Shame : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The West must deploy adequate NATO forces in Macedonia, Kosovo and perhaps Albania before open warfare engulfs these countries too.

nytimes_articles.headline: Haiti's Premier Quits After Four Ministers Refuse to Step Down
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prime Minister Marc Bazin resigned today, saying that the refusal of four ministers to step down after their dismissal had made governing impossible.   Mr. Bazin, appointed by the ruling military nine months after the coup that overthrew the the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, said the actions of the four ministers gave him no choice.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: No Spy Exchange : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: WASHINGTON - The State Department has given a refusal to Germany's demand to have the leading German spy, Rintelen, freed in exchange of Siegfried London, represented as a United States citizen and detained in Germany on a charge of espionage. Germany had

nytimes_articles.headline: Stephen Fry Goes West And Adopts New Look: Jeeves in Cowboy Boots
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stephen Fry has sampled the American West and pronounced it good. The British actor, best known to American audiences as Jeeves on "Masterpiece Theater" and as the title character in the recent film "Peter's Friends," has the Texas twang down pat, and during a recent interview in New York he paced his hotel room wearing a new pair of snakeskin cowboy boots. The accent and the boots were souvenirs of his stay in Texas for a guest role as Oscar Wilde on "Ned Blessing," a nouvelle Western series that CBS plans to introduce in the fall.   Mr. Fry has fond memories of the shoot, which took place near Austin on an authentic-looking Old West set. "I was actually able to say, after lunch, 'Well, I guess I'll mosey down to the corral,' " he said. "And I did, literally, mosey down to the corral."

nytimes_articles.headline: TENSION GROWING IN SOMALI CAPITAL
nytimes_articles.abstract: In anticipation of United Nations military action against Somali armed factions, the exodus of aid workers continued today, and the tension wound tighter with at least five gunfights and sniper attacks reported between Somalis and peacekeepers.   There was also a sense of dread among the Somalis today, and many said they were sending women and children out of the city.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge May Cut Helmsley's Term
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Federal judge indicated yesterday that he was seriously considering a reduction in the four-year prison term currently being served by Leona M. Helmsley, the hotel chain owner, for tax fraud.   "I am considering a sentence reduction which will, in effect, grant her parole," Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan said during a hearing yesterday. "I do not see why she should not be granted parole," he said, citing in particular her age, 72.

nytimes_articles.headline: Of Lost and Founds; They're Home to the Missing, or Even the Stolen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Eileen O'Flaherty has seen her share of strangers' sombreros.   As director of the lost and found department at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it is her job to see that hats, silk pajamas, X-rays, parakeet cages and unpaired shoes are returned to their owners.

nytimes_articles.headline: Royal Wedding in Japan Merges the Old and New
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a Shinto ritual deep in the woods of the Imperial Palace, Crown Prince Naruhito and Masako Owada married this morning with a mix of mystical tradition and a new internationalist air for the world's oldest monarchy.   The wedding marked the fourth time in this century that a future emperor and empress had stepped into the simple wooden shrine behind the palace's high stone walls to sip sake in a national yet private gesture of union.

nytimes_articles.headline: From Japan, a New Hammond Organ
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Hammond organ is back. Sort of. The manufacturer calls it more of an invasion than a renaissance. .Invented by Laurena Hammond in 1934, the first prototype was manufactured in Chicago in 1935. Sound was generated by rotating steel "tone wheels

nytimes_articles.headline: Banks Not Ready Yet For Farewell to Blue
nytimes_articles.abstract: For a football player whose team has told him in effect that it still likes him but does not necessarily love him, Carl Banks is playing it cool. He says he is not angry. He says he is now free to sign with any team, but he also says he still likes the Giants and does not rule out playing for them if the price is right.   "Everything will be O.K., one way or another," Banks said yesterday in an interview. "This is not a bitter situation. It's the way things have worked out. I still think the option is there to play for the Giants, but I don't know the price. I don't know what salary number they have in mind. I don't know if it will be acceptable to me. I'm going to explore the free-agent market. I have 28 options. I want people to understand I didn't get cut."

nytimes_articles.headline: Christopher in Europe to Discuss Plan to Create Havens in Bosnia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Five weeks after Secretary of State Warren Christopher failed to convince the Europeans to embrace an American plan to arm the Muslims of Bosnia, he is back, this time with a different, more modest, agenda.   Having abandoned an American initiative for Bosnia, Mr. Christopher will discuss ways to put into effect a European initiative to protect six "safe havens" for Bosnian civilians. And amid doubts about American leadership in the post-cold-war world, Mr. Christopher may be called on to assure his European partners that the Clinton Administration has not abandoned its role and responsibilities as the world's sole superpower.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mother Nature's Pesticide Factory
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In the environmentalists' war against technology, nowhere are the stakes higher than the assault on pesticides. The current battleground is the Delaney Clause of the Food Additives Amendment of 1958, which bans anything that causes cancer in humans or rodents from being added to processed food. 

The new Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol Browner, in February asked Congress to review the clause, calling it an anachronism that threatened the U.S. food supply. Environmentalists objected loudly, and the E.P.A. quickly retracted her remarks. But Ms. Browner was right: this outdated law should be changed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Toward a Lasting Solution : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: I do not know how the Bosnia mess can be cleared up. But I do know that you cannot clear up a mess by making a bigger mess.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; Of Skinheads High on Hate And Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Romper Stomper," Geoffrey Wright's viscerally supercharged film about neo-Nazi skinheads in Melbourne, Australia, is a film that runs on the adrenaline of hate. From its harrowing opening scene, in which a gang of skinheads terrorizes a group of Vietnamese immigrants, through a prolonged sequence in which the Vietnamese strike back at their tormentors, the film exults at being in the thick of action that is often savagely and sadistically violent.    This being Australia, not the United States, the violence is done with fist, boot, baseball bat and tire chain; not with firearms. But the absence of high-efficiency technological splatter doesn't make it any less bloody or intense.

nytimes_articles.headline: Death Throws A Pall Over The Title Talk
nytimes_articles.abstract: Before a ball could be dribbled, a point scored, a game completed or a championship won, the Chicago Bulls and the Phoenix Suns were sadly forced to put their battle for the National Basketball Association title into a different place today because of the death of Drazen Petrovic of the Nets.    With Game 1 of the N.B.A. championship series on Wednesday night, there was the usual talk of maneuvers and matchups, but mortality seemed foremost on everyone's mind.

nytimes_articles.headline: Toward a Lasting Solution : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations should acquire its own standing military force. Instead of today's peacekeepers working under strict noncombat and zero-casualty rules, the UN force would recruit individual volunteers whose nationality would be irrelevant, for no poli

nytimes_articles.headline: H.I.V. Immunity Discussed at Berlin Conference
nytimes_articles.abstract: A small number of prostitutes in Nairobi, Kenya, appear to have avoided infection with the virus that causes AIDS despite frequent unprotected sex with infected men, researchers said at an international AIDS meeting here today.   The women are of intense scientific interest to researchers, who believe that clues to why they fought off the virus, H.I.V., could lead to the development of vaccines and other therapies.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kelly Has Cure for What Ails Yankees
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Yankees were slipping and sliding on their road trip, turning Buck Showalter's face redder, playing listlessly and ready to plummet in the standings. Their slump stood at three losses in four games, but it felt worse. Much worse.   So on this night when the Yankees needed Jimmy Key to be a stopper and resuscitate a stumbling team, what was Showalter to think when his ace had his shortest outing of the year and was finished before the seventh inning? How much redder could his face get?

nytimes_articles.headline: Diversity on the Supreme Court
